title: Ente paraguayo dice que Yacyretá recibirá entre 100 y 150 millones de dólares tras acuerdo
content: Asunción, 20 may (EFE).- La Entidad Binacional de Yacyretá (EBY) recibirá entre 100 y 150 millones de dólares adicionales, luego de que Paraguay y Argentina firmaran un acuerdo que establece nuevos pr ...
resumen: La Entidad Binacional de Yacyretá (EBY) recibirá entre 100 y 150 millones de dólares adicionales. Paraguay y Argentina firmaron un acuerdo que establece nuevos precios a la energía generada por esta hidroeléctrica. Cada país pagará 28 dólares por megavatios por hora. El acuerdo permitirá «una previsibilidad del despacho de la energía generada». El nuevo convenio permitirá «el reinicio de la obra» en el brazo Aña Cuá del río Paraná y va «a inyectar unos 250 megavatios» a la generación de Yacyretá. Antes del Acuerdo Operativo de EBY, Paraguay abonaba 22 dólares y Argentina, cerca de 50 dólares. Paraguay se compromete a tomar una media de 425 megavatios por hora, sobre el total de 3.100 megavatios de capacidad instalada de la central, lo que permitirá a Argentina acceder hasta un 85 % de la energía disponible. El costo promedio que Paraguay pagaba por la energía era de 22,63 dólares megavatio/hora, mientras que para Argentina oscilaba entre 16 y 17 dólares por megavatio. La binacional factura el megavatio hora a 50 dólares.

title: Unos 6 millones de registros fueron extraídos tras ciberataque a 18 entidades paraguayas
content: Asunción, 20 may (EFE).- Unos 6 millones de registros con información personal de vacunación y registros de proveedores fueron extraídos por piratas informáticos tras los "ataques cibernéticos" sufrid ...
resumen:
Unos 6 millones de registros con información personal de vacunación y registros de proveedores fueron extraídos por piratas informáticos tras los «ataques cibernéticos» sufridos por los sitios web de 18 entidades de Paraguay, según fuentes del Ministerio de Tecnologías de la Información y Comunicación (Mitic).

La «exfiltración (robo) de datos» en los ministerios de Salud Pública y Bienestar Social y de Agricultura y Ganadería se constató a partir del pasado 9 de mayo, dijo el director general de Ciberseguridad y Protección de la Información del Mitic, Pedro Martínez.

Los datos corresponden a información personal como nombre, apellido, dirección o correos proveniente de un «sistema de vacunación» administrado por el Ministerio de Salud.

En el Ministerio de Agricultura hubo otra exfiltración de documentos que contienen información «societaria» sobre «algunos proveedores».

En otras 13 páginas del Gobierno paraguayo se detectó un «defacement» o desfiguración, un tipo de ataque que reemplaza datos de las webs, y en tres casos un «acceso no autorizado» a los sitios web.

Entre los afectados mencionó las páginas del Gabinete Civil de la Presidencia de la República, el Gabinete Militar, la Cámara de Diputados, la Administración Nacional de Navegación y Puertos, la Dirección de Meteorología e Hidrología, la Municipalidad de la ciudad de Pilar (sur), el Servicio Nacional de Catastro, la Caja de Jubilados y Pensionados del Personal Municipal.

Además, los ministerios de Educación y Ciencia, Justicia, Niñez y Adolescencia, Trabajo; y las secretarías Anticorrupción, de Desarrollo para Repatriados, de Deportes, y de Administración de Bienes Incautados (Senabico).

El Mitic presentó este lunes una denuncia penal ante una Unidad Especializada en Delitos Informáticos del Ministerio Público «por ataques cibernéticos contra instituciones del Estado».

Los hechos denunciados incluyen «accesos no autorizados a servidores, interrupciones en servicios públicos digitales, sustracción y difusión de datos sensibles, y actividades maliciosas originadas desde el extranjero».

El actor «principal» que se atribuyó el ataque a través de publicaciones en redes sociales «se hace llamar Cyber Team», que es un grupo «hacktivista», además de otro usuario “particular” que no identificó.

title: Wall Street cierra en rojo y el S&P 500 rompe racha de seis sesiones consecutivas al alza
content: A pesar de las pérdidas para el S&P 500, el selectivo ha subido más del 20% desde que tocara su mínimo en abril.
resumen: Wall Street cerró este martes en rojo y el selectivo S&P 500 rompió así su racha de seis sesiones consecutivas al alza. Al toque de campana, el Dow Jones de Industriales perdió un 0,27% hasta los 42.677 puntos, el S&P 500 cayó un 0,39% hasta los 5.940 enteros y el tecnológico Nasdaq retrocedió un 0,38% hasta las 19.142 unidades. El S&P 500 ha subido más del 20% desde que tocara su mínimo en abril y ahora se encuentra a aproximadamente un 3% de su máximo histórico. Las acciones de Tesla subieron (0,51%). Retrocedieron los principales valores tecnológicos, como Nvidia (-0,88%), Meta (-0,52%), Amazon (-1%), Apple (-0,92%) y Microsoft (-0,15 %). Entre las 30 mayores cotizadas del Dow Jones, subieron UnitedHealth Group (1,8 %), Boeing (1,18 %) y Merck (0,96%) y también cayeron American Express (-1,05%), Goldman Sachs (-0,94%) y Chevron (-0,88%).

title: Exportaciones de iPhone desde China a EE.UU. caen 72% y Apple lanza agresivos descuentos
content: Apple ha intensificado su producción en India, mientras el presidente de los Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, critica esta estrategia. Las caídas de exportación reflejan la fragilidad de las cadenas de s ...
resumen: Las exportaciones de iPhone y otros dispositivos móviles fabricados en China cayeron 72% en abril, alcanzando su nivel más bajo desde 2011, sumando apenas US$700 millones, en medio de una creciente tensión comercial entre China y Estados Unidos. Esta caída supera el descenso general del 21% en las exportaciones chinas hacia EE.UU. durante el mismo mes. El comercio total entre ambos países alcanzó los US$690.000 millones en 2024. Apple enfrenta dificultades en China, con una caída del 9% en sus envíos de smartphones en el primer trimestre de 2025. Para revertir esta tendencia, Apple y plataformas de comercio electrónico como JD.com y Tmall lanzaron descuentos agresivos sobre los modelos iPhone 16, con rebajas de hasta 2.530 yuanes (US$351). JD.com vende el iPhone 16 Pro de 128GB a 5.469 yuanes (US$760), cuando el precio oficial de Apple es de 7.999 yuanes (US$1.110). Tmall ofrece el mismo modelo a 5.499 yuanes. Las autoridades chinas han incluido a los smartphones en su plan de estímulo al consumo, con subsidios de hasta 500 yuanes (US$70) para modelos de menos de 6.000 yuanes (US$830). Apple ha intensificado el traslado de su producción a India. El presidente Donald Trump ha criticado esta estrategia.

title: El dólar global cayó ante señales de cautela por el futuro de la economía en Estados Unidos
content: El dólar global volvía a caer el martes después de una semana de descensos, afectado por la cautela de la Reserva Federal estadounidense (Fed) sobre la economía, mientras los operadores consideraban ...
resumen: El dólar global volvía a caer el martes después de una semana de descensos, afectado por la cautela de la Reserva Federal estadounidense (Fed) sobre la economía, mientras los operadores consideraban la noticia de que las próximas conversaciones entre Estados Unidos y Japón podrían incluir discusiones sobre divisas y evitar la volatilidad.

title: El petróleo se mantuvo estable ante una coyuntura geopolítica en conflicto
content: Los precios absorbieron la incertidumbre en las negociaciones entre EEUU e Irán y entre Rusia y Ucrania. China se desacelera.
resumen: El petróleo operaba estable este martes en medio de movimientos geopolíticos clave como las negociaciones entre Estados Unidos e Irán, y las de Rusia con Ucrania, mientras que nuevos datos entregaron un panorama cauteloso para la economía de China, el principal importador de crudo.

title: Coyuntura. Entre los vaivenes nacionales y la incertidumbre global
content: La volatilidad de la economía global en 2025 junto con la coexistencia de señales contradictorias en la actividad a nivel país perfilan un contexto desafiante, pero aún así pueden encontrarse oportuni ...
resumen:
En 2025, la volatilidad de la economía global y las señales contradictorias en la actividad a nivel país perfilan un contexto desafiante, pero con oportunidades.

El mercado inmobiliario argentino busca señales para la toma de decisiones. El sector inmobiliario regional (Argentina y Uruguay) sigue representando oportunidades estratégicas de inversión.

En Argentina, el crecimiento económico podría aumentar la demanda de propiedades residenciales, comerciales y turísticas. El retorno del crédito bancario, según Luis Signoris (gerente general de CGF), puede marcar una diferencia en el mercado de real estate argentino.

La inversión en real estate sigue siendo una forma segura de proteger el capital a nivel regional.

La construcción tuvo una caída del 27,4% durante 2024, afectando a empresas como FV.

La estabilidad política, leyes seguras y economías estables son fundamentales para atraer inversores extranjeros.

El crédito está en auge, pasando del 4,4% del Producto Interno Bruto (PIB) al 7,5%, según el Informe Monetario Mensual de febrero del Banco Central de la República Argentina (BCRA). Se prevé un crecimiento del PIB cercano al 5% este año, según el Banco Mundial. La desocupación bajó del 7,7% en el primer trimestre de 2024 al 6,4% en el cuarto trimestre de 2024, según el Indec.

El acumulado de enero-abril de 2025 del Índice Construya cerró 10,9% por encima del mismo período del año anterior.

Créditos prendarios a 5 años, hipotecarios reactivados y líneas productivas con tasas competitivas reflejan una nueva visión de los bancos.

Los datos del Índice Construya mostraron un crecimiento mensual e interanual en el sector de la construcción. En abril pasado, la suba fue del 10,44% respecto de marzo en términos desestacionalizados.

Rodolfo Viegener (dueño de la fábrica de griferías Ferrum, del Grupo FV) afirmó que su empresa se encuentra en una situación complicada, atravesando una recesión. En mayo de 2024, la firma suspendió a 800 operarios de la planta de Pilar (provincia de Buenos Aires), donde trabajan 1.400 personas y se fabrican 3.500 artículos.

La construcción tuvo una caída del 27,4% durante 2024. En abril pasado, el Índice Construya (IC) registró una recuperación de 10,44% mensual desestacionalizada, y en la comparación interanual, una suba de 25,8%.

Rodolfo Viegener cuestionó la importación de productos desde China.

title: Trump le da oxígeno a Maduro: prorroga la licencia de Chevron
content: Nuevo balón de oxígeno de la Casa Blanca al régimen de Nicolás Maduro y a las petroleras que con él hacen negocios. La Administración de Donald Trump prorrogará dos meses la licencia de la ...
resumen: La Administración de Donald Trump prorrogará dos meses la licencia de la estadounidense Chevron para operar en Venezuela. El asesor especial de Trump, Richard Grenell, prevé verse en Antigua con enviados de la dictadura de Maduro. En su primer mandato, Trump eliminó los permisos a las petroleras estadounidenses y amenazó con sanciones a las de otros países, incluida la española Repsol. En esta segunda etapa, ha ordenado a las extranjeras salir de Venezuela, pero le sigue prorrogando los permisos a Chevron. La licencia actual de Chevron tenía como fecha límite el 27 de mayo, tras una prórroga previa otorgada ya en marzo. El director ejecutivo de Chevron, Mike Wirth, ha dicho públicamente que un repliegue completo dejaría un vacío que sería ocupado de inmediato por compañías petroleras de Rusia y China. El Tribunal Supremo de EE.UU. permitió la expulsión de 350.000 inmigrantes venezolanos acogidos a un programa de Biden conocido como Estatus de Protección Temporal. Otros 250.000 podrían ser deportados en septiembre. La prórroga de la licencia a Chevron llega tras la liberación de un veterano de la Fuerza Aérea de Estados Unidos, Joseph St. Clair, detenido en Venezuela desde noviembre. Su excarcelación se produjo el martes, en Antigua, donde fue entregado por enviados de Maduro a Grenell. En las conversaciones en Antigua participó Jorge Rodríguez, presidente de la Asamblea Nacional chavista.

title: LATAM DAY AHEAD-Noticias e Indicadores de América Latina (20 de mayo)
content: LA AGENDA DEL MARTES ESTADOS UNIDOS -El presidente del Banco de la Reserva Federal de Atlanta, Raphael Bostic, realiza las declaraciones de bienvenida a la Conferencia de Mercados Financieros 2025, en ...
resumen:
**LATAM DAY AHEAD-Noticias e Indicadores de América Latina (20 de mayo)**

**ESTADOS UNIDOS:**

*   Raphael Bostic, presidente del Banco de la Reserva Federal de Atlanta, realizará las declaraciones de bienvenida a la Conferencia de Mercados Financieros 2025, en Fernandina Beach, Florida (1300 GMT).
*   Mary Daly, presidenta de la Fed de San Francisco, y Beth Hammac, presidenta de la Fed de Cleveland, ofrecerán notas de apertura y Raphael Bostic moderará un debate de la Conferencia sobre Mercados Financieros 2025: "Intermediación financiera en transición: ¿Cómo se adaptará la política?", organizada por el Banco de la Reserva Federal de Atlanta, en Fernandina Beach, Florida (2300 GMT).
*   Thomas Barkin, presidente de la Fed de Richmond, intervendrá en la Conferencia "Investing in Rural America", en Roanoke, Virginia (1300 GMT).
*   El Banco de la Reserva Federal de Boston publicará las declaraciones de la presidenta Susan Collins antes de un evento cerrado "Fed Listens" en Keene, Nuevo Hampshire (1330 GMT).
*   Alberto Musalem, jefe de la Reserva Federal de San Luis, hablará sobre la economía y la política monetaria de Estados Unidos ante el Economic Club of Minnesota, en Mineápolis, Minnesota (1700 GMT).
*   Adriana Kugler, gobernadora de la Reserva Federal, pronunciará el discurso de graduación en la ceremonia de graduación de Economía de Berkeley de primavera de 2025, Berkeley, California (2100 GMT).
*   El Instituto Estadounidense del Petróleo (API) divulgará su sondeo semanal de inventarios de crudo (2030 GMT).

**ARGENTINA:**

*   El Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Censos reportará las cifras de la balanza comercial de abril (1900 GMT).

**RESTO DEL MUNDO:**

*   Los ministros de Economía y los gobernadores de los bancos centrales del G7 se reunirán en Banff, Alberta, Canadá.

**MERCADOS GLOBALES ACTUALIZADOS:**

*   **CHINA TASAS:** China recortó las tasas de interés de referencia de los préstamos por primera vez desde octubre, mientras que los principales bancos estatales redujeron las de los depósitos.
*   **BCE TASAS:** Isabel Schnabel, miembro del Comité Ejecutivo del BCE, dijo que el Banco Central Europeo (BCE) está en vías de conseguir que la inflación vuelva a su objetivo del 2%, pero los nuevos retos, entre ellos la guerra comercial mundial, pueden hacer que los precios suban aún más, por lo que el banco debería dejar de relajar su política monetaria.
*   **AUSTRALIA TASAS:** El banco central de Australia recortó su principal tasa de interés en 25 puntos básicos, hasta situarla en el mínimo de dos años del 3,85%.

**CATL:**

*   Las acciones del gigante chino de baterías para vehículos eléctricos CATL cotizaban hasta un 18,4% por encima del precio de suscripción, después de que la empresa recaudó 4.600 millones de dólares en su debut bursátil en Hong Kong. Las acciones de CATL alcanzaron los 311,40 dólares hongkoneses cada una, después de que la empresa vendió sus acciones a 263 dólares de Hong Kong cada una en la cotización.

**LATAM STARTUPS:**

*   El capital recaudado para empresas emergentes en América Latina creció 26% en 2024 respecto a 2023.

**IRÁN EEUU:**

*   El ayatolá Alí Jamenei dijo que las exigencias estadounidenses de que Teherán se abstenga de enriquecer uranio son "excesivas e indignantes".

**LO QUE HAY QUE SABER DEL LUNES:**

*   **FED CALIFICACIÓN:** Los responsables de la Reserva Federal asumieron con cautela las ramificaciones de la rebaja de la calificación crediticia del Gobierno estadounidense.
*   **EEUU IMPUESTOS:** Los republicanos en la Cámara de Representantes buscarán aprobar esta semana la ley fiscal del presidente Donald Trump.
*   **UCRANIA RUSIA:** Donald Trump dijo que Rusia y Ucrania "comenzarán inmediatamente las negociaciones" hacia un alto el fuego, pero el Kremlin dijo que el proceso llevaría tiempo.
*   **MÉXICO CRECIMIENTO:** La actividad económica de México creció un 0,7% en abril en relación con igual mes del año anterior.
*   **EEUU MIGRACIÓN:** La Corte Suprema de Estados Unidos permitió al Gobierno de Donald Trump despojar del estatus de protección temporal a unos 350.000 venezolanos.
*   **VENEZUELA VUELOS:** Diosdado Cabello ordenó suspender los vuelos hacia y desde Colombia.
*   **OMS PANDEMIAS:** Los miembros de la Organización Mundial de la Salud (OMS) votaron a favor de un tratado mundial para mejorar la preparación ante pandemias. Unos 124 países votaron a favor, sin votos en contra y 11 abstenciones.

title: Wall Street cierra a la baja; el S&P 500 registra su primera caída en siete días
content: Los precios de las acciones cayeron el martes en la Bolsa de Valores de Nueva York, ya que Wall Street perdió impulso después de haberse recuperado de un profundo bache.

title: Trump Scolded Companies for Raising Prices. Do They Have a Choice?
content: Economists say companies generally have to pass along the cost of tariffs. But populists on the left and right say the president may have a point.
resumen:
El presidente Trump se quejó el sábado de que Walmart debería "dejar de culpar a los aranceles" por los inminentes aumentos de precios.

El año pasado, el presidente Joseph R. Biden Jr. citó la "avaricia corporativa" como la razón por la que los estadounidenses pagaban más por la gasolina, los alimentos y el alquiler, al tiempo que desviaba las críticas de que sus políticas habían empeorado la inflación.

Michael Strain, economista del American Enterprise Institute, dijo que en ambos casos, el presidente comete un error de política, lo que lleva a un aumento de los precios al consumidor, y el presidente culpa a las empresas.

Los aranceles del Sr. Trump, que se fijan en el 30 por ciento sobre las importaciones chinas hasta mediados de agosto, tendrán efectos en toda la economía, ya sea empujando los precios al alza para los consumidores o, si las empresas absorben algunos de los costos, reduciendo las ganancias para las empresas. Esas respuestas podrían impulsar la inflación, frenar el crecimiento y aumentar el desempleo.

Elizabeth Wilkins, presidenta del Roosevelt Institute, dijo que la idea básica de que las empresas tienen más poder de fijación de precios de lo que se cree es algo que se debe interrogar.

El Sr. Trump sugirió que Walmart usara sus miles de millones en ganancias del año pasado, "mucho más de lo esperado", para proteger a los consumidores contra los aumentos de precios.

Chad Syverson, economista de la Universidad de Chicago, dijo que el tamaño de las ganancias de una empresa tiene poco efecto en su decisión de aumentar los precios. La mayoría de las empresas quieren preservar sus ganancias, ya sean grandes o pequeñas, porque no hacerlo incurriría en la ira de sus propietarios o accionistas, algunos de los cuales son fondos de pensiones e inversores a pequeña escala.

Alexander MacKay, economista de la Universidad de Virginia, dijo que si, en algunos casos, las empresas aumentan los precios incluso más que el aumento de sus costos, eso no refleja necesariamente un comportamiento nefasto. Puede reflejar el hecho de que los consumidores ya no se sienten tan desanimados por los aumentos de precios.

Jared Bernstein, que se desempeñó como principal economista de la Casa Blanca del Sr. Biden, dijo que muchos consumidores durante la pandemia estaban menos disuadidos de lo habitual por los aumentos de precios porque estaban inundados de una serie de inyecciones de efectivo del gobierno.

Oren Cass, ex asistente de política republicano, dijo que una gran empresa como Walmart tenía mucha más influencia sobre sus precios de lo que dejaba ver.

John David Rainey, director financiero de Walmart, dijo que la empresa estaba "bien equipada" para navegar por los aumentos de precios del 2 o 3 por ciento, pero no por un arancel del 30 por ciento, la tasa actual sobre los bienes de China. El Sr. Rainey agregó que Walmart de hecho absorbería algunos de los aumentos de costos.

Nick Iacovella, vicepresidente ejecutivo de la Coalición para una América Próspera, señaló una lógica dudosa en la fijación de precios por parte de las empresas: un fabricante de automóviles gritará sobre la necesidad de aumentar los precios cuando los costos aumenten, pero cuando un fabricante de automóviles aprovecha un acuerdo comercial para trasladar la producción a México, rara vez traslada los ahorros a los consumidores.

Ms. Wilkins, del Roosevelt Institute, argumentó que las grandes empresas no solo aumentaban los precios cuando sus costos aumentaban, o cuando los compradores se mostraban dispuestos a pagar más. Dijo que las empresas a veces explotaban las preocupaciones generalizadas sobre la inflación para manipular los precios.

Dr. MacKay, el economista de la Universidad de Virginia, concedió que este tipo de coordinación era posible. Señaló un estudio reciente que argumentaba que los ejecutivos de la industria aérea se han coordinado eficazmente para reducir los asientos en las rutas competitivas telegrafiando sus intenciones durante las llamadas de ganancias.

Noam Scheiber es un reportero del Times que cubre a los trabajadores de cuello blanco, centrándose en temas como la remuneración, la inteligencia artificial, la movilidad descendente y la discriminación.

title: What Trump’s Phone Call With Putin Reveals About His View of the World
content: The two leaders talked for more than two hours—and they probably didn't spend much of it discussing the prospects for peace.
resumen: Presidents Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin talked Monday for more than two hours but made not an inch of progress toward ending the Russia–Ukraine war. Trump said afterward that he believes Putin wants peace. Trump wants the war to end quickly only so that the U.S. and Russia can resume good relations—and if this means Ukraine’s surrender, so be it. Trump hailed the “tone and spirit” of their conversation as “excellent.” Putin, in a formal statement, deemed the talk “frank and useful.” Trump has called for an “immediate ceasefire.” Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky endorsed the idea. Putin never has. Earlier on Monday, several European leaders urged Trump to renew the demand during his conversation with Putin. Trump ignored their plea. Putin continued to insist that prior to a ceasefire, the two combatants must address the war’s “root causes”—which, in Putin’s mind, amount to the very existence of Ukraine as a sovereign state with its own language, culture, and aspirations to align with Europe. Trump didn’t challenge Putin on this point. He also told reporters that he would not impose sanctions or any other punishment on Russia, regardless of Putin’s actions. He said that Russia and Ukraine would have to hold negotiations on their own. Trump is acknowledging that Putin, not Zelensky, is the one resisting a ceasefire—yet if Russia stays on that course, the U.S. won’t step up its support for Ukraine; instead, Trump will simply pull out. Trump has said that without firm U.S. support, Russia will win the war. The day before the much-anticipated phone call, Russia slammed Ukraine with one of the largest drone attacks since the war began—yet Trump didn’t so much as mention it in their talk. The two leaders talked for more than two hours about trade. Russia wants to do largescale TRADE with the United States when this catastrophic “bloodbath” is over, and Trump agrees. There is a tremendous opportunity for Russia to create massive amounts of jobs and wealth. Its potential is UNLIMITED. Ukraine too “can be a great beneficiary on Trade, in the process of rebuilding its Country”. To the extent a coherent foreign policy is emerging in Trump’s second term as president, it is centered around three goals: trade, the promotion of “great-power politics,” and peace at any price in order to promote the first two.

title: US importers race to create bonded warehouses amid Trump tariffs
content: Companies importing goods into the United States from China are rushing to convert warehouses into facilities that are exempt from President Donald Trump's tariffs until they are ready to sell the ...
resumen: Companies importing goods into the United States from China are rushing to convert warehouses into facilities that are exempt from President Donald Trump's tariffs until they are ready to sell the merchandise. The U.S. has more than 1,700 bonded warehouses, facilities where imported goods can be held without immediate payment of customs duties such as tariffs, currently 30% for shipments from China. Such fees are only paid when the goods leave the bonded warehouse. The rush to bond U.S. warehouses for goods ranging from clothing to auto parts is a bet for some that raised U.S. tariffs will be only a short-term policy by the Trump administration. Due to Trump's tariff war, many of these bonded warehouses are now at full capacity, and prices for space in them have skyrocketed, four industry sources told Reuters, prompting companies to apply to U.S. Customs and Border Protection to expand bonded space. Utah-based fulfillment firm LVK Logistics is in the process of making one of its warehouses bonded "in response to the tariffs," CEO Maggie Barnett told Reuters, adding she expects the process to take three to four months. Chris Rogers, who manages the supply chain research team at consultancy S&P Global Market Intelligence, said, "It involves money and it takes time, but if you are a big company and expect tariffs are going to remain elevated for an extended period, you can convert (existing) spaces into bonded warehousing." Chris Huwaldt, vice president of solutions at WarehouseQuote, a logistics research firm, said other companies and logistics firms are seeing their applications with the CBP backlogged in some cases by over six months. Last year, the process would have taken a couple of months. Huwaldt said getting storage space certified as bonded "could cost thousands of dollars or it could cost six figures," depending on the state the warehouse is based in, the financial status of the company and the additional security measures required by the CBP for a specific location. Trump's on-again, off-again tariff policy - which pushed duties on Chinese goods to as much as 145% in April before lowering them - makes the flexibility afforded by bonded warehouses appealing to companies. Cindy Allen, shipping consultant at Trade Force Multiplier and a former FedEx Logistics executive, said, "A lot of companies importing from China - not just China-based, but U.S. importers as well - are taking advantage of bonded warehouses to assist with cash flow." The CBP said it has noticed an increased interest in the use of bonded warehouses for continued compliance with new regulations and executive orders. In early 2024, bonded storage space was rented at approximately twice the cost of standard storage rates, but since the start of 2025, it has risen to four times the price to rent non-bonded space, according to WarehouseQuote data. Allen said, "This rush to bonded warehouses to ease cash flow is unprecedented." During the first Trump administration, many companies simply accepted the levies on China. Vladimir Durshpek, cofounder of Venice, Florida-based warehousing and storage company CargoNest, said he is weighing adding a third bonded warehouse to his assets until U.S. tariff negotiations are completed. Fremont, California-based storage company DCL Logistics has not made definitive plans for bonded space because "it's unclear if the demand will stay this high," Chief Revenue Officer Brian Tu said. Jacob Roseburrough, director of marketing at WarehouseQuote, said, "By the time a lot of warehouses would be able to achieve bonded status right now, these additional tariffs might be gone, and the demand for bonded space might not be there."

title: China’s smartphone exports to US crash to 14-year low amid trade war
content: The decline in smartphone export reflects a dramatic fallout from escalating trade tensions and renewed tariff threats.
resumen: China’s smartphone exports to the US have plunged to their lowest level since 2011. In April 2025, China’s mobile phone shipments to the US plummeted 72 per cent year-on-year to $688.5 million, the lowest monthly figure since June 2011, according to China’s General Administration of Customs, as reported by Bloomberg and Trade Data Monitor. This collapse outpaced the 21 per cent overall drop in Chinese exports to the US in the same period. Smartphones led the decline in export value in April 2025, with a month-on-month drop of $1.8 billion. The Trump administration has imposed tariffs of up to 145 per cent on select Chinese goods, including mobile phones and electronics. In 2024, US-China bilateral trade totaled $690 billion. Apple Inc. is accelerating its shift of iPhone production to India. According to China’s General Administration of Customs, the value of smartphone component exports from China to India has roughly quadrupled over the past year. India now hosts Apple’s largest iPhone production base outside of China.

title: Tariffs trigger price hikes: Shoes, clothing and toys to get more expensive this summer
content: Skyrocketing prices might not be top of mind this spring. But many economists warn that consumers should get ready to pay more as soon as summer.
resumen: Consumers can expect big price spikes on clothing and shoes this year. The consumer price index rose year-over-year by 2.3% in April. Consumers should get ready to pay more for some things as soon as summer. Some shoppers might want to keep an eye on Memorial Day sales. Spikes in shoe prices could get people talking. Shoe prices are expected to be 15% higher and apparel prices are expected to be 14% higher in the short run, according to the Budget Lab. The report issued May 12 estimated the effects of all U.S. tariffs and foreign retaliation implemented in 2025 through May 12. Overall, we could see an average per-household consumer loss of $2,800, the Budget Lab reported, as a result of higher tariffs. The price level from all 2025 tariffs rises by 1.7% in the short run. Exactly when we'll pay higher prices on individual items will vary. Hallmark acknowledged that it "made the necessary decision to adjust pricing on select imported products from our gift and ornament collections that are impacted by the current economic climate." On May 15, Walmart said it would have to start raising prices on many goods later in May and June to address higher costs associated with tariffs. The price of bananas at Walmart rose to 54 cents a pound, up from 50 cents, thanks to higher tariffs. The Budget Lab analyzed the May 12 tariff rates as if they stayed in effect in perpetuity. As of May 12, the U.S. and China agreed to a reduction in tariffs for 90 days as negotiations continue. The May 12 changes to the China rate alone reduce the negative economic impact of all 2025 tariffs to date by 40%, according to the Budget Lab. U.S. consumers still face an overall average effective tariff rate of 17.8%, the highest since 1934, according to the estimates from the Budget Lab. Without the lower China tariffs − but with a trade deal between the United States and the United Kingdom and newly proposed auto rebates − the average effective tariff rate would have been 27.6%. Consumers could have a bit of calculating to do when it comes to how much they might be willing to buy early and how willing they might be to hold off shopping. It is substantially uncertain where China tariffs in particular are going to end up over the summer. If there are significant tariffs on China still in place this summer, it’s highly likely they will put upward pressure on apparel and electronics prices for back-to-school shopping. Consumers could experience sticker shock when they shop for a long list of items. Price tags on many goods will start reflecting the impact of tariffs by June and July. Consumers probably will see price increases on clothing and apparel; footwear; toys and games; and small electrical appliances, including microwaves, toasters and mixers. Price hikes might also be expected for household items for bathrooms, including items made of plastic; children's car seats and strollers; and some types of furniture. Percentage increases in the double-digit range seem probable for items like toys, car seats and strollers. The Toy Association, which has more than 900 members, is urging the U.S. government to grant a reprieve from tariffs on toys imported from China. The New York Post ran a Page One cover May 1 declaring: "Skimp on the Barbie." As of May 13, a 10% tariff on goods entering the United States is to stay in place. Inflation isn't bad now. Prices fell on some items in April, including airline tickets and used cars and trucks. PNC Chief Economist Gus Faucher noted in his report that consumers saw little indication in the April CPI report of tariffs causing higher goods prices. Tariffs are likely to drive prices and inflation up over the next few months. Diane Swonk, KPMG's chief economist, noted in a report: "This could be the last benign inflation report for a while." Major footwear manufacturer Wolverine Worldwide stated in its earnings report that it would not provide a full-year 2025 outlook as a result of "uncertainty around tariffs and related macro-economic conditions." Wolverine Worldwide shoe brands include Merrell, Saucony, Hush Puppies, Chaco and Stride Rite. The recent de-escalation with China to lower tariffs from 145% to 30% for 90 days is welcome news, according to an economic outlook issued May 13 by KPMG. The KPMG report indicated that the Federal Reserve "is not expected to cut rates until December due to a bout of stagflation, a period of rising inflation coupled with escalating unemployment." Charles Ballard, professor of economics emeritus at Michigan State University, said uncertainty is just off the charts. Baby strollers, baby car seats, cell phones, laptops and toys, are some of the items that face the greatest uncertainty.

title: Global retailers' tariff strategy risks spreading pain beyond US consumer
content: Global retailers including sandal maker Birkenstock and jeweller Pandora are looking at spreading the cost of U.S. tariffs by raising prices across markets to avoid big hikes in the United States that ...
resumen:
Global retailers including sandal maker Birkenstock and jeweller Pandora are looking at spreading the cost of U.S. tariffs by raising prices across markets to avoid big hikes in the United States that could hurt sales.

Birkenstock's chief financial officer said last week that a "low-single-digit" price increase globally would be enough to offset the U.S. tariff impact.

Pandora CEO Alexander Lacik said the Danish company is debating whether to raise prices globally or more in the U.S., its biggest market.

Markus Goller, partner at consultancy Simon Kucher in Bonn, Germany, said that a manufacturer from outside of the U.S. might increase prices slightly in the U.S., and slightly in Europe, and in other markets.

U.S. President Donald Trump has imposed a blanket tariff of 10% on all global imports and is threatening higher so-called "reciprocal" tariffs on its trading partners.

When U.S. behemoth Walmart said it would have to raise prices in response to tariffs, Trump ordered the world's biggest retailer via social media to 'eat the tariffs'.

Jean-Pierre Dubé, professor of marketing at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business, said that retailers don't want to be accused by the White House of raising prices purely because of U.S. tariffs, so if they can demonstrate that their prices are going up everywhere then... it's kind of a shield.

Jason Miller, professor of supply chain management at Michigan State University, said that retailers could raise prices on certain products or in certain markets where consumers are less price-sensitive, and use that to subsidise other products or countries where price hikes would hurt sales more.

Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey raised the issue of "global companies that don't make that distinction [on tariff rates] and just say, we're going to impose a pricing solution which goes right across the world irrespective of those differences."

In the euro zone, inflation was finally gliding towards the European Central Bank's 2% target.

European companies surveyed by the European Central Bank (ECB) in late March said price growth in the retail sector was subdued.

Trump unveiled his tariff policy on April 2, and later hiked tariffs on Chinese goods to 145%.

The U.S. tariffs on China - lowered last week to 30% - have allowed some European retailers to source goods more cheaply than before.

Martino Pessina, CEO of Takko Fashion, which sells clothes in 17 European countries, said suppliers in China had offered lower prices as U.S. retailers cancelled orders from factories there, and shipping costs also fell.

Adidas CEO Bjorn Gulden told investors after reporting results late last month that there is no reason to raise prices outside the U.S. because of the tariffs.

ECB executive board member Isabel Schnabel has said the euro zone's inflation rate may initially dip below the central bank's 2% target, but that tariffs might prove inflationary further down the road.

Hal Singer, professor of economics at the University of Utah, warned that some could take advantage of tariffs to raise prices by more than rising costs, boosting their profits similarly to the inflation surge of 2021-2022 during the pandemic.

U.S. consumers' 12-month inflation expectations jumped in April to 6.7%, the highest reading since 1981.

Miller said that if people are expecting inflation, it gives firms a little bit more room to raise prices.

title: Is Walmart raising prices? What MA shoppers should know about Trump tariff price increases
content: Prices at Walmart will likely start going up later this month due to President Donald Trump’s tariffs, executives said on May 15.
resumen:
Prices at Walmart will likely start going up later this month due to President Donald Trump’s tariffs, executives said on May 15.

Many items sold at Walmart, like food, toys, clothing, electronics and back to school items, are expected to increase in price.

In Massachusetts, there are 27 Walmart Supercenters and 21 discount stores located across the state.

Prices at Walmart will likely start going up later this month due to President Donald Trump’s tariffs, executives said on May 15.

"We will do our best to keep our prices as low as possible but given the magnitude of the tariffs, even at the reduced levels announced this week, we aren't able to absorb all the pressure given the reality of narrow retail margins," CEO Doug McMillon said in a statement.

U.S. shoppers will start to see prices rise at the end of May and certainly in June, Walmart's Chief Financial Officer John David Rainey said in a CNBC interview.

While Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said retail giant Walmart "will be absorbing" the impact of tariffs on CNN’s “State of the Union” Sunday, he also said that some costs "may get passed on to consumers."

Tariffs are taxes on foreign goods shipments to the U.S. They are paid by importers: in this case, American manufacturers or retailers. The cost is typically passed along to consumers in the form of higher prices.

Many items sold at Walmart, like food, toys, clothing, electronics and back-to-school goods, are expected to increase in price.

McMIllan said in an earnings call that “food inflation is very much on our mind,” according to CNN. The company said that already, the price of bananas at Walmart has risen four cents a pound because of higher tariffs.

According to The Budget Lab at Yale, a non-partisan policy research center, consumers can expect to see 15% higher shoe prices and 14% higher apparel prices in the short run, with the rates going up in the long run. Their May 12 report estimates the effects of all U.S. tariffs and foreign retaliation implemented through May 12, including the currently lower tariff rates on China.

The U.S. also imports a large volume of toys, baby gear and electronics from China, meaning that prices are likely to go up on those items. Mattel, the maker of Barbie, said that it planned to raise prices on its toys because of the tariffs. (Barbie is sold at Walmart.)

Trump too acknowledged that some toys might get more expensive, saying in an interview with ABC in early May that "maybe the children will have two dolls instead of 30 dolls," and that "maybe the two dolls will cost a couple bucks more than they would normally."

Seasonal products, like back-to-school gear, could also get more costly as those purchases can’t be delayed.

“If there are significant tariffs on China still in place this summer, it’s highly likely they will put upward pressure on apparel and electronics prices for back-to-school shopping," Ernie Tedeschi, director of economics at The Budget Lab at Yale University, told the Detroit Free Press.

It’s still unclear exactly when and where the price hikes will hit, especially as tariff rates are still in flux. But The Budget Lab’s report predicts an average per household consumer loss of $2,800.

In Massachusetts, there are 27 Walmart Supercenters and 21 discount stores located across the state.

Some Supercenter locations include Fall River, Leominster, Plymouth, Tewksbury, Walpole and Worcester.

title: Actividad económica en el país perfila estancamiento
content: La economía mexicana se estancó en los últimos meses y apunta a un mayor debilitamiento, afectada principalmente por la contracción en la actividad industrial. En marzo registró un crecimiento anual ...
resumen:
La economía mexicana se estancó en los últimos meses y apunta a un mayor debilitamiento, afectada principalmente por la contracción en la actividad industrial.

En marzo registró un crecimiento anual de apenas 0.2 por ciento y de 0.7 por ciento en abril, medida con el Indicador Oportuno de la Actividad Económica (IOAE).

Las actividades secundarias registraron una caída anual del 1.3 por ciento en marzo y del 0.80 por ciento en abril. En tanto, las actividades terciarias avanzaron 1.1 por ciento anual en marzo y 1.5 por ciento en abril.

A tasa mensual, tras un avance de 1.0 en febrero, el IOAE subió 0.2 por ciento en marzo, y reportó un nulo crecimiento en abril, de acuerdo con los registros del Inegi.

Para analistas de Banamex, de materializarse estos resultados, el crecimiento del PIB en el primer trimestre habría sido de 0.2 por ciento trimestral.

Julio Santaella, expresidente del INEGI, indicó que “con el resultado obtenido en el bimestre, la actividad económica regresa a su senda de estancamiento, lo cual deja ver que el efecto de febrero fue inusitado”.

Arturo Vieyra, economista en jefe de grupo Coppel, mencionó que entre los factores clave que han impedido un mejor desempeño de la economía están las amenazas arancelarias del presidente Donald Trump, que han inhibido la inversión, pero, además, la debilidad en el PIB de Estados Unidos.

El PIB en EU tuvo una contracción del 0.3 por ciento en el primer trimestre de este año, respecto al trimestre anterior, y a esto añadimos que la política fiscal en México es restrictiva, con un ajuste en el gasto que se ubicó 8.4 por ciento por debajo para el presupuesto de este periodo.

Para el resto del año se espera una persistencia en la debilidad económica, y estimó un crecimiento del 0.1 por ciento anual.

De acuerdo con Gabriela Siller, directora de análisis económico de Grupo Financiero Base, los datos del IOAE sugieren que la economía seguiría mostrando signos de reducción en abril y los próximos meses.

Señaló que se estima un crecimiento de cero por ciento para todo el año, en un escenario central; de 0.5 por ciento en un escenario optimista y una caída de 1.0 por ciento en el escenario pesimista.

Para Jorge Peña, catedrático de la Facultad de Economía de la UNAM, los resultados de marzo y abril evidencian la fragilidad de la situación económica.

Aunque el sector servicios muestra resiliencia, es probable que no sea suficiente para contrarrestar el mal desempeño de la industria.

Andres Abadia, economista en jefe para Latinoamérica de Pantheon Macroeconomics, advirtió que los segmentos clave de la industria siguen con un bajo dinamismo.

El sector de la construcción no tiene impulso, la minería está limitada en su desarrollo, y aunque los servicios crecen, ya no es suficiente para compensar el mal comportamiento del sector secundario.

title: The commodities feed: Trump-Putin call yields little progress
content: Oil prices remain steady as the market digests the Trump-Putin call, which appears to have resulted in no significant breakthroughs.
resumen:
Oil prices remain steady as the market digests the Trump-Putin call, which appears to have resulted in no significant breakthroughs.
The scheduled call between President Trump and President Putin doesn’t appear to have led to any significant breakthroughs.
Trump said that Russia and Ukraine would begin talks on ending the war.
Putin said the main aim remains to “eliminate the root causes of the crisis”.
There was no threat of further sanctions on Russia or a timeline for negotiations.
There are concerns that with Trump leaving negotiations to Russia and Ukraine, the US might step back from its role as mediator.
Iranian nuclear talks appear to be hitting some stumbling blocks.
The US has said that any deal with Iran must include a suspension of uranium enrichment, which is a red line.
Iran has said that it is “absolutely non-negotiable”.
Chinese refiners processed a little under 14.2m b/d of crude oil in April, down 5% month-on-month and 1.3% lower year on year.
Apparent oil demand fell to 13.8m b/d last month, down 3.9% MoM and 5.3% lower YoY.
US natural gas prices came under significant pressure yesterday.
Front-month Henry Hub futures settled more than 6.6% lower on the day.
Readily available aluminium inventories in London Metal Exchange (LME) warehouses jumped by 92,950 tonnes to 343,025 tonnes yesterday.
Aluminium prices on the LME fell more than 1% in yesterday’s trading.
Chinese output reached a record high last month.
Primary aluminium output in April rose 4.2% year-on-year to 3.75m tonnes (flat with the March level).
For the year-to-date period, output rose 3.4% year-on-year to 14.79m tonnes, according to the latest data from China’s National Bureau of Statistics.
The USDA’s weekly US crop progress report for the week ending 18 May shows domestic corn plantings stood at 78% complete.
US soybean plantings are 66% completed as of 18 May.
The agency rated around 52% of the winter wheat crop in good-to-excellent condition.
Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT) corn prices are likely to remain largely under pressure.

title: Pres. Trump lobbies House Republicans
content: President Donald Trump tries to blame Democrats as support for this "big, beautiful bill" faces tough questions on Capitol Hill.
resumen: President Donald Trump headed to Capitol Hill Tuesday with a stern message to House Republicans to stay in line and support his multi-trillion tax and spending bill. President Donald Trump turned up the pressure, telling wavering House Republicans to support what he calls his “big, beautiful bill” or face the political consequences. Behind closed doors, the president told the House Republican Conference that they all must unite behind his multi-trillion dollar budget bill. White House sources say the President warned that any Republican who doesn’t back the bill could face a primary opponent. “You have a couple that will grandstand, but I think even the grandstand is look, the alternative is a 68% tax increase. And you can blame the Democrats for that. And 1 or 2 grandstanding. We only have one issue, but we have tremendous support.” The president urged fiscal conservatives to give up their push to expand Medicaid cuts and some moderate Republicans to drop their efforts to raise the cap on state and local tax deductions. The president’s bill would extend tax cuts due to expire in December, boost border spending, and repeal much of President Biden’s Inflation Reduction Act. Democrats are unified in opposition to the legislation. That includes Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer who continues to criticize the President’s trade tariffs policy. On the floor of the Senate, Minority Senator Chuck Schumer (D- N.Y.) said, “For someone who fancies himself a shrewd businessman, Donald Trump doesn’t seem to understand the pain his trade war has created for businesses.” Despite the President’s arm twisting, his Capitol Hill visit appeared to fail to sway some key Republicans from more liberal states and conservatives who want steeper cuts to the federal budget deficit. Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.) has a very narrow majority in the House. The House Rules Committee has called a meeting for the unusual time of 1am ET Wednesday.

title: There’s some good news for Trump’s approval rating, latest poll shows
content: The latest Morning Consult poll showed 48% of voters approving of Trump’s job performance—his highest approval rating Morning Consult has recorded since mid-March. The poll showed that half of the ...
resumen: President Donald Trump’s approval rating ticked up following his Middle East trip last week, a new poll showed. The latest Morning Consult poll showed 48% of voters approving of Trump’s job performance—his highest approval rating Morning Consult has recorded since mid-March. The poll showed that half of the voters still disapproved of Trump’s job performance, but that dropped two percentage points since last week. According to the poll, Trump’s approval ratings on foreign policy and his handling of trade also improved. The poll found that voters are “evenly divided over Trump’s handling of trade.” The poll found that Trump’s strongest policy area continues to be immigration, where 53% of voters approve of his handling of it. He continued to receive low marks on the economy, with 47% of voters disapproving of how he is handling it. Morning Consult’s Eli Yokley also explained that last week, Trump also received his “best news week” since February. The latest poll was conducted May 16-19 among 2,208 registered U.S. voters. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 2 percentage points. The latest Harvard CAPS/Harris poll showed that 46% approved of how Trump is handling the economy, which is up from the 43% who said the same last month. Another 43% said they approved of how Trump is dealing with inflation, which is up two percentage points from last month. A recent Reuters/Ipsos poll, released Tuesday, found Trump’s approval rating ticked up two percentage points since the poll was conducted late last month. The poll found that 44% of respondents said they approved of Trump’s job performance, while 52% say they disapproved. The Quantus Insights poll showed a virtual tie, with 48.2% of respondents saying they approve of Trump while 48.3% said they disapprove. According to Reuters, former President Joe Biden had a 55% approval rating at a similar point in his presidency.

title: Israel’s Allies Condemn Expansion of Gaza War
content: Britain, France and Canada called the Israeli plans for escalation “disproportionate” and “egregious” at a time when the U.N. is warning the population is at risk of famine.
resumen:
Israel’s threats to drastically escalate the war in Gaza and its blockade of humanitarian aid to a Palestinian population at risk of famine have drawn sharp condemnation from some powerful Western allies.

Britain said it was suspending talks with Israel on expanding a free-trade agreement. Britain, France and Canada issued a rare public reprimand of Israel, demanding it cease the renewed military offensive.

A joint statement by the three countries said: “We have always supported Israel’s right to defend Israelis against terrorism. But this escalation is wholly disproportionate.”

Israel is threatening to take full control of Gaza and has been blocking humanitarian aid from Gaza for more than two months, even as the U.N. warns that the population is under threat of famine.

Israel said it would begin allowing some humanitarian aid to flow into Gaza. Authorities let only five trucks in on Monday.

A senior U.N. humanitarian official, Tom Fletcher, told the BBC on Tuesday that 14,000 babies in Gaza could die in the next 48 hours unless truckloads of aid could enter. He said thousands of trucks, some containing baby food, were ready to move in.

Britain, France and Canada called the expanded Israeli campaign against Hamas in Gaza and the withholding of aid “egregious actions” that cannot continue.

The statement said: “If Israel does not cease the renewed military offensive and lift its restrictions on humanitarian aid, we will take further concrete actions in response.”

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Britain, France and Canada had handed a “huge prize” to Hamas. He accused them of tacitly encouraging a repeat of the Oct. 7, 2023, attacks, that killed some 1,200 people in Israel, with 250 taken as hostages to Gaza.

Mr. Netanyahu said: “This is a war of civilization over barbarism. Israel will continue to defend itself by just means until total victory is achieved.”

Israel has killed more than 53,000 Palestinians in Gaza, according to Gazan health officials.

President Trump has increasingly bypassed Mr. Netanyahu, cutting a separate deal with Hamas to free the last living American hostage and skipping Israel on his trip to the Middle East last week.

Mr. Trump said “a lot of people are starving” in Gaza under the Israeli blockade and the United States wanted to help alleviate the suffering.

Foreign Secretary David Lammy announced in Parliament the suspension of free-trade talks with Israel, condemning what he said were Mr. Netanyahu’s plans to “drive Gazans from their homes into a corner of the strip to the south and permit them a fraction of the aid that they need.”

European officials have privately expressed “increasing frustration and even anger with Israeli actions in Gaza.”

In March, Israel ended a two-month cease-fire with Hamas that would have freed the hostages in exchange for an end to the war and a full Israeli withdrawal. Mr. Netanyahu has said Israel could not accept anything less than for Hamas to disarm and its leaders to go into exile.

The United Nations said that the handful of trucks allowed through the Kerem Shalom Crossing were not enough amid a dire humanitarian situation in the Palestinian encalve.

Jean-Noël Barrot, the French foreign minister, said the E.U. could decide to suspend its agreement with Israel unless the Gaza offensive were halted.

title: How Trump's budget bill & tax cuts would impact the US economy
content: As Congress considers President Trump's tax and budget plan, Citi economist Veronica Clark joins Market Domination to discuss what the bill becoming law would mean for the US economy. To watch more ...
resumen: Citi economist Veronica Clark discusses the impact of President Trump's tax bill on the US economy. The bill's impact on the deficit is expected to be flat, around 6% of GDP, which means a pretty flat impulse for growth. The debt servicing costs and interest expense will be an increasing part of the deficit. The tariff increase on China is around 30%, which could be passed on to consumer prices. The Fed's preferred inflation measure, core PCE inflation, is around 2.5% and could be closer to 3% by the end of the year. The consumer was weakening before the tariffs, and consumption could be slowing. Savings rates are very low, delinquencies are pretty high, and student loan repayments are starting soon. The Fed is effectively frozen for the near term, waiting for the next data point. The labor market may start to weaken before concerning signs of price increases. The unemployment rate has risen in the last couple of years due to a loosening labor market driven by very low hiring.

title: What if Trump ditches tariffs too quickly to see a real effect?
content: I hope Trump pushes forward on tariffs. Hear me out. He has already backtracked faster than a hiker who spies a rattlesnake. Trump spent the first weeks of his second term spitting out tariff rates in ...
resumen: Trump has backtracked on tariffs. On Feb. 1, he announced 25% tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada (along with a 10% tax on goods from China) and then reversed himself. On Feb. 3, he decided upon a 30-day pause on Canada/Mexico tariffs. Trump announced that the Mexico/Canada tariffs were suspended. This continued for several more weeks (a 200% tariff on Champagne and wine from the EU, 25% tax on cars and parts, a tariff on movies, carve-outs for various electronics, copper, lumber, etc.) culminating in “Liberation Day” on April 2, when Trump announced a national emergency to justify a suite of tariffs. After “Liberation Day,” the world reeled. The European Union, China and other nations announced retaliatory tariffs, and markets crashed. The obliteration of $8.5 trillion in wealth between April 2 and April 8 occurred. On April 9, he suspended the “Liberation Day” levies for 90 days — though he tacked on an additional 145% tariff on China. On May 12, he climbed down even from those. The overall average effective tariff rate is 17.8% — the highest since 1934. It was 2.5% when Trump took office in January.

title: Tariffs live updates: China iPhone exports to US plunge to 14-year low amid tariff tensions
content: On Tuesday, it was reported that Chinese shipments of Apple's iPhone and mobile devices to the US fell to their lowest since 2011 in April. The sharp drop highlights how US tariff ...
resumen: Chinese shipments of Apple's (AAPL) iPhone and mobile devices to the US fell to their lowest since 2011 in April. The Port of Los Angeles saw shipments drop by as much as 30% in early May. Importers and retailers, especially those linked to China, were among the most affected. Port of Los Angeles Executive Director Gene Seroka said Monday that the impact was felt almost immediately during that first week of May. JPMorgan (JPM) CEO Jamie Dimon said Monday that markets are underestimating the long-term impact of tariffs, calling the current duties “pretty extreme.” He flagged rising risks of inflation and stagflation. Citigroup’s (C) Jane Fraser noted companies are delaying investments amid tariff uncertainty. Walmart (WMT) previewed coming price hikes. Trump told the company to "eat the tariffs.". Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said on Sunday that tariff rates will go back to "reciprocal" levels if countries do not make trade deals with the US during the 90-day pause. The US is prioritizing trade deals with 18 key partners. Trump said Friday that the US will set tariff rates for its trading partners within the next few weeks. Atlanta Federal Reserve President Raphael Bostic suggested that businesses may be exhausting the strategies they can use to avoid price or employment changes. Former Medtronic CEO Bill George said that the world's CEOs welcome signs of progress on US trade deals. George, who has sat on the boards of Target (TGT), ExxonMobil (XOM), and Goldman Sachs (GS), said he's telling CEOs to be ready to deploy capital once more trade clarity emerges. The 90-day trade truce between China and the US appears to have done little to ease Beijing’s tight control over its rare earth exports. China’s pledge to suspend or remove the “non-tariff” countermeasures imposed on the US since April 2. US trade representative Jamieson Greer said that the Chinese have agreed to remove those countermeasures. Walmart said that the tariffs would lead to price hikes. Trump encouraged them to "eat the tariffs." Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent relayed that he had spoken to Walmart CEO Doug McMillon — and that McMillon had told him that the company "will be absorbing" some of the costs. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt claimed that Trump has "always maintained" that "Chinese producers" will absorb tariff costs. The European Commission has warned that tariff uncertainty is pushing euro-area inflation below the European Central Bank’s target for next year.

title: Why Trump's tariffs will lead to recession, even after he caved to China | Opinion

title: China Demonstrates High Cost Of Trumpian Uncertainty
content: Not big moves, but symbolic ones as U.S. President Donald Trump’s trade war takes an increasing toll on Chinese confidence. So far, Trump’s tariffs haven’t tackled Asia’s biggest economy in the ways ...
resumen: China's 5.4% growth rate in the first three months of the year is impressive. The People’s Bank of China cut its key lending rates by 10 basis points. Governor Pan Gongsheng lowered the one-year loan prime rate to 3.0% from 3.1%, and the five-year rate to 3.5% from 3.6%. U.S. President Donald Trump’s trade war is taking an increasing toll on Chinese confidence. China grew above its 5% target in the first quarter while the U.S. shrank 0.3%. Data releases showed signs of the high cost of economic uncertainty. Softening data on retail sales, fixed asset investment, property prices, industrial production and other sectors are showing a chilling effect. Trump has pared his 145% China tax to 30%. This climbdown could be short-lived if Chinese leader Xi Jinping doesn’t offer Trump concessions. Trump’s 30% level puts the tax in the neighborhood of the 1930s Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act. Prior to January 20, China was struggling with a giant property crisis that’s fueling deflation, near-record youth unemployment, a rapidly aging population and local governments dealing with trillions of dollars of debt. Factory-gate prices have been falling for 31 consecutive months. In April alone, producer prices dropped 2.7% year on year. Consumer prices are now down for three straight months. The PBOC’s rate cut was its first since October, when it moved by 25 basis points. Fears that the yuan might fall too far, too fast had Pan avoiding rate cuts. "Today's reductions ... probably won't be the last this year," says Zichun Huang, China economist at Capital Economics. The rate cuts will reduce interest payments on existing loans, taking some pressure off indebted firms. It will also reduce the price of new loans. Modest rate cuts alone are unlikely to boost loan demand or wider economic activity meaningfully. "We still believe it will be quite challenging for Beijing to achieve its 'around 5%' growth target unless it rolls out a sizable stimulus package," says Ting Lu, chief China economist at Nomura. A 30% tariff on all shipments to the globe’s biggest economy is no joke. Economic uncertainty comes at a very high price.

title: China's smartphone exports to US hit decade low since 2011 amid tariff tensions
content: According to the report, smartphone shipments from China to the US dropped 72% year-on-year to just under $700 million last month. This steep fall far exceeded the overall 21% decline in Chinese ...
resumen: Smartphone exports from China to the US dropped 72% year-on-year to just under $700 million last month. This steep fall far exceeded the overall 21% decline in Chinese exports to the US during the same period. Chinese exports of Apple Inc.’s iPhones and other mobile devices to the United States fell to their lowest level in over a decade in April. The looming threat of US tariffs has disrupted the flow of high-value electronics between the two countries. The Trump administration’s tariff strategy â with levies reaching as high as 145% on Chinese imports â is severely impacting technology supply chains and shifting electronics production to other countries. Beijing has accused Washington of derailing recent negotiations in Geneva by pursuing additional sanctions targeting Huawei Technologies Co.âs AI chip business. In 2024, smartphones, laptops, and lithium-ion batteries ranked among the top US imports from Beijing, while China imported valuable commodities such as soybeans, oil, and semiconductor manufacturing machinery from the US. Chinese exports of phone components to India rose, with volumes roughly quadrupling over the past year. Apple has its largest iPhone production base outside China in India. Former President Trump recently criticized the move and urged the company to bring production back to the US.

title: India’s stock market rated above Japan and China by more fund managers: survey
content: Fund managers are confident that India will benefit more from the US-China trade war, according to the Bank of America Securities survey.
resumen: Según una encuesta de Bank of America Securities, India ha sido calificada como la principal opción de mercado de valores en Asia por los administradores de fondos de riqueza. Aproximadamente el 42 por ciento de los administradores de fondos tienen una posición de sobreponderación en las acciones indias, por delante de Japón con el 39 por ciento y China con solo el 6 por ciento. La encuesta, publicada el 13 de mayo, recopiló información de 109 panelistas que gestionan un total combinado de 234 mil millones de dólares estadounidenses en activos, quienes respondieron preguntas del banco entre el 2 y el 8 de mayo. El informe cita a los estrategas de Bank of America, diciendo que "India emerge como el mercado más favorecido, percibido como un probable beneficiario de las realineaciones de la cadena de suministro tras los efectos de los aranceles".

title: General Motors stops exporting made-in-US vehicles to China amid ongoing trade tension
content: General Motors has decided to stop exporting cars from the United States to China, as tensions rise between Washington and Beijing over trade. The move comes shortly after a temporary truce in the ...
resumen: General Motors has decided to stop exporting cars from the United States to China, as tensions rise between Washington and Beijing over trade. The move comes shortly after a temporary truce in the trade war between the two countries, which saw both sides agree to reduce tariffs for 90 days. US-based automotive giant General Motors informed its employees and dealers in China on Thursday that it will cease exporting cars from the United States to China. GM had been exporting cars to China through its Durant Guild premium import business, which accounted for less than 0.1 per cent of its total sales in the country, according to a company spokesperson. The spokesperson said they are restructuring The Durant Guild and streamlining GM Chinaâs operations due to significant changes in economic conditions. Previously, goods imported from the US to China faced tariffs of over 100 per cent, until both countries agreed to temporarily reduce them for 90 days. In April, GMâs rival Ford also halted its exports to China. As part of the agreement, both countries decided to cut tariffs for 90 days. US tariffs on Chinese goods dropped from 145 per cent to 30 per cent, while Chinese tariffs on US goods fell from 125 per cent to 10 per cent.

title: Global Economic Officials Gather Amid Headwinds From Trump’s Trade War
content: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent will meet his international counterparts at a G7 finance ministers meeting in Canada.
resumen: Top finance officials from the world’s wealthiest economies began gathering in Canada on Tuesday for meetings. The summit of the Group of 7 finance ministers is likely to be more fraught this year. The tariffs that Mr. Trump has imposed on American allies and adversaries have threatened to blunt global growth and inflame inflation. Europe, Japan and Canada have all been bearing the brunt of the Trump administration’s “America First” economic agenda. The three days of meetings will include support for Ukraine, concerns about China’s economic practices and headwinds facing the global economy. Mr. Trump’s trade tactics will dominate the discussions between Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and his counterparts. François-Philippe Champagne, Canada’s finance minister, said at an opening news conference on Tuesday, noting that during recent meetings with American officials in Washington, “there was always tension around tariffs.” Mr. Bessent, who skipped a gathering of the Group of 20 finance ministers in February, will appear at the international forum for the first time. Mr. Bessent plans to make the case that countries need to get “back to basics” and take steps to address “imbalances and nonmarket practices,” according to a Treasury Department spokesman. Mr. Bessent is also expected to prioritize expressing the Trump administration’s concerns about China’s excess industrial capacity. The Group of 7 is made up of the United States, Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan. Mr. Trump has upended the global trading system with a blizzard of tariffs. He imposed a 10 percent universal tax on almost every trading partner, in addition to 25 percent tariffs on imported steel, aluminum, cars and car parts. He raised tariffs on China to a punishing 145 percent in April before reducing them to 30 percent this month. In April, Mr. Trump hit dozens of countries with “reciprocal” tariffs before pausing those levies for 90 days. Mr. Bessent and other Trump officials have said the administration is working to strike deals by July 8 with 18 to 24 trading partners, including Argentina, Malaysia, Israel, Switzerland, India, Japan, Vietnam, South Korea and Thailand. The United States and the European Union have also been negotiating over trade terms. Mr. Bessent warned that higher tariffs could kick in if negotiations with those nations faltered during the 90-day pause. Mr. Bessent said on CNN on Sunday that the United States was focused on completing agreements with a short list of partners, and that other parts of the world, like Central America or Africa, could see their tariff rates set through regional deals instead. The U.S. and Chinese governments are also starting to communicate more frequently in an effort to make progress on their trade spats. Gene Seroka, the executive director at the Port of Los Angeles, who sits on a trade advisory council for the Trump administration, said at a news conference on Monday that the administration was working constructively toward framework deals. Mr. Trump had threatened the biggest levies since the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930. At the Group of 7 meeting of finance ministers in Canada that year, France’s finance minister at the time, Bruno Le Maire, said the club had become the Group of 7 plus one, with the United States on the outskirts. Mr. Trump’s first-term Treasury secretary, Steven T. Mnuchin, was sent home from the gathering with a stern rebuke. In a joint statement that year, finance ministers from the European Union, Canada and Japan “requested that the United States secretary of the Treasury communicate their unanimous concern and disappointment.” Mr. Bessent maintained that the United States was not retreating from the global stage. Although Mr. Trump has demonstrated a willingness to walk back some of his trade measures, the scale and scope of the tariffs that he has already announced have dwarfed those from his first term. The dominance of the trade disputes could also overshadow many of the other matters that have been central to the Group of 7 meetings, like efforts to combat climate change, the rise of artificial intelligence and working together to address China’s manufacturing subsidies. It is not clear the officials will be able to reach consensus on a joint statement, or communiqué, when the meetings conclude on Thursday.

title: Australian central bank cuts interest rates amid global economic turmoil
content: The Reserve Bank board statement referred to “the heightened level of uncertainty” in the world economy and said it had “considered a severe downside scenario.” ...
resumen: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) board cut its official cash rate by 25 basis points for the second time in three months, reducing the rate to 3.85 percent, down 50 points overall from 4.35 percent. This decision reflects growing concern about the impact of the Trump administration’s trade war. The decision will have only a marginal effect on home mortgage payments and rents. A household with a $750,000 mortgage could see their minimum monthly repayments fall by $228 a month as a result of the two rate cuts. The RBA’s decision was overshadowed by global economic turmoil generated by the US Trump administration’s trade war, particularly against China. The board used the word “uncertain” 134 times in its statement. The board considered a severe downside scenario. The RBA stated that “Geopolitical uncertainties also remain pronounced. These developments are expected to have an adverse effect on global economic activity, particularly if households and firms delay expenditure pending greater clarity on the outlook. This has also contributed to a weaker outlook for growth, employment and inflation in Australia.” The RBA governor Michelle Bullock described the situation over the past few months as a “roller coaster” and “unpredictable.” There was a risk of a recession in Australia. One of the scenarios in the board’s statement estimates that unemployment could jump to 6 percent, which would mean about 900,000 out of work, if the US-China trade conflict worsened. The RBA downgraded its key economic forecasts, lowering its projections for growth in exports, business investment and household consumption, and slashed its forecasts for US economic activity. China accounted for 37 percent of all exports in 2024. Japan, South Korea and India together took 24 percent of the exports last year. The United States is the largest foreign investor in Australia, with its investment stock reaching $1.17 trillion in 2023, accounting for a quarter of the total of $4.7 trillion invested in Australia at the end of 2023. Stephen Miller wrote that the upending of the global trade system occasioned by the Trump administration’s tariff agenda will constitute severe headwinds for the global economy. Interest rates on US Treasury bonds are soaring. Moody’s rating agency joined other agencies in stripping the US government of its AAA credit ranking. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation’s chief business correspondent Ian Verrender warned: “Bond markets are now openly questioning America’s place in the global financial system and remain unconvinced about Washington’s ability or commitment to strike a lasting peace in its trade wars.” Australia’s major banks are among the biggest institutional borrowers in the world, tapping global markets for about $30 billion to $40 billion every year. S&P Global warned that Australia’s AAA credit rating could be at risk due to mounting government budget deficits unless the Albanese government cut social spending. According to the RBA’s calculations, “the combined drag from higher interest rates, lower gross mixed income (mainly small business income) and tax has reduced disposable income by 5 percentage points since December 2019.” The official Wages Price Index rose 3.4 percent over the 12 months to the March 2025 quarter. The RBA’s core inflation rate has eased to 2.9 percent. Living costs for employee households rose 3.4 percent over the 12 months to March, and by an annual rate of 4.4 percent during the March 2025 quarter. In April, the official jobless rate remained 4.1 percent. Employment vacancies fell 9.3 percent over the preceding year. An estimated 621,000 people were counted as unemployed, seasonally adjusted, but the number of job vacancies had fallen to 328,900. For workers aged 15 to 24, the official youth unemployment rate remained more than twice as high at 8.9 percent.

title: Colombia debe aprovechar la guerra comercial entre China y EE. UU.
content: En la guerra comercial entre China y EE. UU., Colombia y Latinoamérica deben aprovechar para impulsar integración regional e industrialización estratégica.
resumen:
El autor, Diógenes Rosero Durango, profesor universitario, historiador económico y experto en temas de desarrollo y democracia, analiza la guerra comercial entre China y EE. UU. y cómo Colombia podría aprovecharla.

El autor menciona que una guerra comercial no beneficia a nadie, especialmente a economías medianas o pequeñas como las latinoamericanas, y que ya se siente el aumento de la inflación internacional y la volatilidad de las monedas, incluyendo la devaluación del peso colombiano en 2025.

El autor se pregunta si Colombia y Latinoamérica pueden aprovechar esta situación. Señala precedentes históricos, como el reemplazo de la inactividad industrial europea por manufacturas de Japón y América Latina a finales del siglo XIX, y el desarrollo de Corea después de la Segunda Guerra Mundial.

El autor considera inevitable el despegue de China como líder económico y los choques con sus competidores. Menciona que Trump intenta proteger a EE. UU. en la fase final de la supremacía china, olvidando a sus socios comerciales tradicionales.

El autor propone que Colombia consolide una política de estado, incluyendo la comisión de relaciones internacionales. También sugiere actuar como bloque, retomando la agenda de integración regional.

El autor destaca la necesidad de un liderazgo que aglutine y convenza, y de consolidar una agenda de temas estratégicos como narcotráfico, medio ambiente, desigualdad y reindustrialización.

El autor observa que Colombia y Brasil se acercan a China, mientras que Panamá parece ceder ante el pragmatismo estadounidense. Concluye que acercarse a China puede convenir, pero advierte sobre los riesgos y la importancia de llenar los vacíos que deja EE. UU. en Europa y la región de forma prudente y estratégica.
