title: UK economy grows above forecasts, but tariffs threaten progress
content: Britain's economy grew more than expected in the first quarter, official data showed Thursday, covering the period before business tax hikes and US President Donald Trump's tariffs blitz took effect.
resumen:
Britain's economy grew 0.7 percent in the January-to-March period.
Economists expected a 0.6 percent increase.
The data comes as a boost for Prime Minister Keir Starmer and his Labour government.
UK finance minister Rachel Reeves said the figures "show the strength and potential of the UK economy," while acknowledging that "there is more to do".
Thursday's data covers the period before April's introduction of a hike to a business tax laid out in the Labour government's maiden budget in October.
It also precedes a baseline 10-percent tariff imposed on the UK and other countries by Trump last month.
Capital Economics chief UK economist, Paul Dales, said "This might be as good as it gets for the year".
Yael Selfin, chief economist at KPMG UK, said the growth spurt is "set to be short lived as tariffs take effect”.
The US deal reduces tariffs on British cars and removes those on steel and aluminium, while in return Britain will open up markets to US beef and other farm products.
The baseline 10-percent tariff remains intact.
Selfin said, "the indirect impact of trade tensions between the US and the EU will further constrain demand for UK exports".
ONS director of economic statistics Liz McKeown said that "the economy grew strongly in the first quarter of the year, largely driven by services, though production also grew significantly, after a period of decline."
Analysts attributed the rebound in production to manufacturers rushing to get ahead of the implementation of Trump's tariffs.
UK exports of goods to the United States increased for the fourth consecutive month in March.
The ONS said, "This pattern of increasing exports could be a sign of changing trader behaviour ahead of tariff introduction."
Economists at Pantheon Macroeconomics cautioned, "Any residual support for manufacturing from front-running will fade from here on, pointing to activity remaining weak for the foreseeable future".
The ONS estimated that monthly GDP grew 0.2 percent in March, from an increase of 0.5 percent in February.
The Bank of England last week cut its key interest rate by a quarter point to 4.25 percent.
The BoE also upgraded its outlook for annual GDP for 2025 to one percent growth from 0.75 percent, but lowered next year's outlook to 1.25 percent from 1.5 percent.
Data on Tuesday showed that unemployment hit its highest level since 2021 in the first quarter.

title: 4 macro trends reshaping food and beverage
content: Shoppers’ resiliency is tested in the face of numerous macroeconomic conditions, including high food prices and tariffs, which will have implications for the food and beverage industry for years to ...
resumen:
Four macro trends reshaping food and beverage:

1.  Economic uncertainty fuels changes:
    *   Consumers have grown accustomed to uncertainty over the last five years.
    *   The next market shock is around the corner, which will drive growth of specific categories and products.
    *   Consumers look to value and wellness.
    *   Globalization has been retreating for more than a decade.

2.  High food prices set up future shocks:
    *   Consumers are navigating a world of higher food prices.
    *   The Consumer Price Index for food rose 2.8% in April, above the Fed’s target of 2%.
    *   Consumers are less likely to weather further market shocks with food prices being high now.
    *   Income and food prices are rising hand-in-hand, meaning consumers spend a larger percentage of their income on groceries.

3.  The premium and innovation crunch:
    *   High food prices have a “smothering effect” where “everything else just becomes secondary in consumers’ mindsets.”
    *   Innovation continues to be sluggish.
    *   A third (35%) of CPG launches in the first four months of 2024 were net new products – the lowest level of innovation since 1996.
    *   The cost of product development increased.

4.  Wellness becomes a necessity:
    *   Consumers will focus on products with wellness claims.
    *   A third of consumers said they will prioritize health and wellness in the next 12 months.
    *   Consumers want to invest in themselves and their loved ones.
    *   Matthew Barry, insights manager at Euromonitor International, outlined these trends during an International Dairy Deli Bakery Association webinar.

title: Tariff truce raises Jakarta’s bargaining power
content: The government views the apparent de-escalation in a trade war between the United States and China as an opportunity to demand open and fair trade in its own negotiations with a highly protectionist ...
resumen:
The government views the apparent de-escalation in a trade war between the United States and China as an opportunity to demand open and fair trade in its own negotiations with a highly protectionist US administration.

Washington and Beijing announced in a joint statement on Monday that they had agreed to bring triple-digit import tariffs on each other’s export goods down to two figures and continue negotiations.

The US government agreed to bring down its fresh duties of 145% on many imports from China to 30%, while China, which had retaliated by imposing 125% tariffs on US-made products, agreed to reduce the duties to 10%, according to US President Donald Trump.

Those rates are to apply for 90 days as the two sides work on a long-term agreement.

Finance Ministry spokesperson Deni Surjantoro said on Tuesday that the development “underlined the effectiveness of diplomacy and negotiations in taking down trade barriers”.

The ministry is among three institutions spearheading bilateral talks with the White House to avert a 32% import tariff threatened to be imposed on most Indonesian products exported to the United States.

The exorbitant levy, described by Washington as a “reciprocal” measure, took effect on April 9, but its enforcement was suspended hours later for a 90-day period to provide time for bilateral negotiations.

The spokesperson said the ministry viewed the latest developments between China and the United States as a “de-escalation” that would have a “positive impact” on global trade and investor sentiment.

He went on to say that the easing tension would improve supply chains and may even shift global trade in “a more diversified but still interconnected” direction.

Deni said that Indonesia can take advantage of this momentum to strengthen its bargaining position in multilateral or bilateral forums, push for more open and fair trade, as well as ensuring that national interests are safeguarded amid the ever-developing global dynamics.

Raden Pardede, an official at the Office of the Coordinating Economic Minister, said the US-China de-escalation could translate into lower reciprocal tariffs worldwide, “because the main cause of the tariff war is the competition between those two big countries”.

He said the preliminary deal carved out by Beijing and Washington could become a benchmark for Jakarta in its own tariff negotiations with the US government.

However, “Trump’s moves remain unpredictable”, Raden said, which was why the government would be on its toes and remain ready to mitigate and react to any “unexpected action”.

Indonesian Employers Association chairwoman Shinta Kamdani suggested on Tuesday that the tariff landscape was evolving too rapidly to make out any universal connecting thread.

Shinta said that the archipelago had to be ready to anticipate the unexpected with regard to the global situation, and, in the meantime, the focus should be on fixing waning consumer spending within the country.

Household spending, which consistently accounts for over half of Indonesia’s economic activity, has lagged behind overall gross domestic product (GDP) growth in recent years.

Bank Permata economist Faisal Rachman pointed out in a media briefing on Wednesday that, despite the latest agreement, the duties imposed by the United States and China on each other’s products were still higher than before the tariff war began.

He said that that would impact Indonesia’s GDP growth “indirectly” on account of slowing demand from China, the archipelago’s largest trade partner.

The “direct effect” for Indonesia, said Faisal, would mostly play out in seven industries that relied heavily on the export market, particularly the US market, with little scope to redirect sales to the domestic market.

The vulnerable industries, according to Faisal, were textile and wearing apparel; rubber and products of rubber and plastic; metal products, computer, electronic, optical and electric equipment; wood, articles of wood and woven goods of bamboo, rattan and the like; machinery and equipment; furniture and other manufacturing as well as; leather, leather products and footwear.

Bank Permata chief economist Josua Pardede said “if the Chinese and US governments have begun to soften their respective positions”, then Washington could be more conciliatory toward Jakarta.

Josua said Jakarta’s offers, which included a US$2bil investment in a blue ammonia project from Indorama, was “a proposal Trump could not refuse”.

title: Trade skirmish will affect the US the most
content: The panic associated with Trump tariff is gradually receding, thanks to US administration’s recent climbdown on duties ...
resumen: The Trump-Tariff (TT), unfolding since January 2025, is widely perceived as counter-productive public policy. A tariff war between China and the US led to unprecedented uncertainties and disruptions in the global trade/supply chains. The US economy is likely to bear the heaviest burden of TT. Within two days of its announcement on April 2, the US stock market lost $5 trillion. The US economy is heading for a deep slowdown, if not a recession, evidenced by a fall in consumer confidence and economic outlook. In its April 2025 World Economic Outlook, the IMF predicted that the US economy would grow by 1.8 per cent in 2025 compared to 2.8 per cent in the previous year. Even a 1.8 per cent US growth in 2025 has become doubtful due to negative growth in January-March 2025. The US dollar index has declined below 100 since mid-April 2025, from nearly 110 on January 13, 2025. The US trade deficit of $1.2 trillion in 2024 was alarming. The 90-day moratorium on reciprocal tariffs is fast approaching. The additional reciprocal tariff imposed on India is relatively lower at 26 per cent.

title: Consumers Prop Up the Economy. They’re Showing Signs of Strain.
content: What matters most, however, is the labor market. “If American consumers have money, they’re going to spend it, and the primary place they get money is through their jobs,” said Eric Winograd, an ...
resumen: The U.S. consumer has seemed unstoppable in recent years, spending throughout soaring inflation and the highest borrowing costs in decades. Consumer spending has fueled the economy. President Trump’s tariffs and their rollout have raised concerns that the United States may soon face an economic downturn. Consumer spending accounts for more than two-thirds of U.S. economic activity. Consumers are still spending, although more slowly than in the past. Their attitudes about the economic outlook have soured in recent months in anticipation of elevated prices, slower growth and higher unemployment. Americans have also become choosier about how they spend their money. Leisure and business travel has declined. People are buying fewer snacks and eating out less as they look to cut costs. They are even doing fewer loads of laundry to save money. The economy is vulnerable. A stockpile of savings that consumers accrued as a result of government stimulus during the pandemic and a booming stock market has largely been tapped out. The highest-earning 10 percent of Americans, who drive the bulk of consumer spending, are still in good shape, but it’s the bottom 90 percent that worry her most. The share of outstanding credit card debt that is 90 days or more past due started increasing in 2023 and has continued to rise across geographies and income levels, according to data through the first quarter of this year released Tuesday by the New York Fed and research by the St. Louis Fed. The trend has become particularly pronounced for poorer households. Real-time credit reports from Experian suggest the pace accelerated in April. The overall delinquency rate, which includes all loan types, reached its highest level since 2020 in the first quarter of this year, according to the Fed data. This was driven by student loan delinquencies, as past-due student loans once again were included in credit reports after a pandemic-era pause on federal student loan repayments. The labor market is noticeably less robust than it was in the aftermath of the pandemic. Businesses are still hiring, layoffs are low and the unemployment rate has stabilized at a historically low level of around 4 percent. Companies are posting far fewer job openings and positions are no longer much more plentiful than the number of people looking for work as businesses reassess their staffing needs in an environment of slowing growth. Spending is now consistently increasing faster than income, once adjusted for inflation. Either incomes will need to accelerate or consumption must slow over time. Pay is no longer soaring for workers in the lowest-paid industries, such as leisure and hospitality, who saw their earnings increase the fastest in the initial recovery period when the job market was strong and demand for their services was high. Now, pay is rising faster in high-wage industries — as pay for lower- and mid-wage jobs stagnate. Wage growth has slowed, particularly for workers in low-wage industries. Policymakers at the Federal Reserve do not appear too worried just yet and are taking their time to assess the economic impact of Mr. Trump’s policies before restarting interest rate cuts. John Williams, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said in a recent interview.

title: Alain Frachon: 'The three-month pause in the US-China trade war offers a reprieve. However, it is not over'
content: COLUMN. A structural imbalance has set in between the two countries, which goes beyond Chinese mercantilism and the irresponsibility of American capitalists, notes Le Monde columnist Alain Frachon.
resumen:
Alain Frachon: 'The three-month pause in the US-China trade war offers a reprieve. But it is not over'.
A structural imbalance has set in between the two countries, which goes beyond Chinese mercantilism and the irresponsibility of American capitalists, notes Le Monde columnist Alain Frachon.
The three-month pause in the trade war between the two countries, announced in Geneva, on May 12, offers a reprieve.
Washington has lowered the outrageous tariff barrier Trump imposed on Chinese exports to the US by 115 points – from 145% to 30%.
In response, Beijing had retaliated with a 125% protective tariff at Chinese borders, which has now been reduced to 10%.
The battle over tariffs may be experiencing a lull, but it will continue nonetheless: It is one facet of the China-US confrontation.
Donald Trump aims to free America from its dependence on Chinese products; Xi Jinping wants his country to be as autonomous as possible.
Trump has highlighted China's role in some of the American economy's weaknesses: deindustrialization, trade deficit, a multifaceted addiction to "made in China" products.
The American accusation denounces Chinese practices, such as predatory trade tactics, competition skewed by subsidies and other monetary manipulations, and the lack of social and environmental standards.
China has constructed the world's leading industrial base and prioritizes its development on the limitless expansion of its exports.
On May 12, The New York Times cited the objective Xi set for Chinese economic leaders, in April 2020: to promote other countries' dependence on China in international value chains.
Trump has rightly criticized the global trade imbalances inherited from the past 40 years of free trade, he is wrong about China's exclusive responsibility.

title: Board game designer suing the Trump administration reacts to lowered tariffs against China
content: The Trump administration reduced tariffs against China from 145% to 30% over the weekend. The lowered rate elapses after 90 days.
resumen: The Trump administration reduced tariffs on China from 145% to 30%. Those lower rates are set to elapse after 90 days. Jamey Stegmaier, board game designer and president of Stonemaier Games, said he felt a sense of relief. Stegmaier's company, known for games like “Wingspan” and “Scythe,” operates out of St. Louis, Missouri, but manufactures games in China. The “Liberation Day” 145% tariff threatened his industry so profoundly that he decided to sue the Trump administration over its authority to levy such taxes. Stegmaier is rushing to import games from China before the 90-day window closes. Stegmaier said that the reason that board games like the ones that they make aren't made in the US is largely due to the level of precision and variety and customization that China has got really, really good at handling at scale. Stegmaier said that the main impact of the 145% tariffs was what types of games can they consider that they can make in the U.S. at scale. Stegmaier said that they can't make any products that they already make consistently in the U.S. because they already have a partner that can make those games consistently in China. Stegmaier said that they are making a much more modest holiday print run than normal. Stegmaier said that they manufacture 100% of the games that they make in China. They ship around 65% of them to the U.S. The other 35% go to the rest of the world. They are working with their partner in China, Panda, which is actually a Canadian company, to potentially start moving some production to Brazil.

title: Is the trade war over already?
content: World trade has been severely disrupted over the past five weeks or so, and it sounds reasonable to conclude that it will take more than a couple of months for trade to get back to pre-tariff levels.
resumen: Risk appetite surged at the beginning of this week following an unexpected breakthrough in US-China trade talks. Investors were caught off guard by the announcement at 08:00 BST on Monday, which put some detail on reports that the two sides had enjoyed productive discussions over the weekend. The meet-up in Geneva between US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Chinese Vice Premier He Lifeng was simply a preliminary discussion to agree on the terms of engagement for more protracted and in-depth discussions. The talks brought something far more substantive. It was stated that both China and the US would slash their respective import tariffs by 115% for 90 days as of 14th May. This took levies down to 10% for Chinese imports from the US, and to 30% for US imports from China. The US tariff included an additional 20% with respect to fentanyl. The deal provided a reasonable basis for further talks to take place over the next three months. President Trump later insisted that, most importantly, the talks have opened up China to US businesses. US stock indices soared on the news, as did the US dollar and crude oil. Precious metals slumped. All four of the major US stock indices have now recouped the losses they suffered in the aftermath of President Trump’s reciprocal tariff announcement on 2nd April. In addition, Dow excepted, the S&P 500, NASDAQ and Russell 2000 have hit levels last seen in late February and early March. That means that the S&P and NASDAQ are closing in on their all-time highs from mid-February.

title: Sanctions no more? Syria’s war-torn economy braces for life after Assad
content: US President Donald Trump has said he will lift long-standing sanctions on Syria that severed the country from the global financial system under toppled ...
resumen:
US President Donald Trump has said he will lift long-standing sanctions on Syria. The European Union and Britain have already lifted some of their sanctions.

The World Bank estimates Syria’s economy is worth around US$21 billion (RM90 billion). Official Syrian data shows the economy more than halved in size between 2010 and 2022. Nighttime light emissions indicated an 83 per cent contraction between 2010 and 2024. Syria was reclassified as a low-income country in 2018, with more than 90 per cent of its near 25 million population living below the poverty line, according to UN agencies.

The exchange rate was at 11,065 pounds to the dollar on Wednesday. Black market rates were around 22,000 around the time of Assad’s fall last year and just 47 to the dollar in March 2011. Maysaa Sabrine is the central bank governor.

The government has stated its owes between US$20 billion and US$23 billion mostly in bilateral loans, although it could be considerably higher given it may face claims from Iran and Russia for between US$30 billion to US$50 billion.

The central bank only has foreign exchange reserves of around US$200 million in cash. It also holds nearly 26 tonnes of gold too, worth over US$2.6 billion. The new government has said it expects to retrieve up to US$400 million of its frozen assets. Switzerland has said some 99 million Swiss francs (US$118 million) worth are currently in banks there. The Syria Report newsletter also estimates that 163 million pounds worth (US$217 million) are in the UK.

Syria’s exports decreased from US$18.4 billion in 2010 to US$1.8 billion in 2021, according to the World Bank. Captagon production became the most valuable economic sector, with World Bank last year putting the total market value of the drug originating from Syria as high as US$5.6 billion.

In 2010, Syria exported 380,000 barrels per day (bpd) of oil. Syria was reliant on energy imports — mostly from allies Russia and Iran. Rachel Ziemba, senior adviser on sanctions with risk consultancy Horizon Engage, said the roughly 1-3 million barrels of fuel per month Syria had been getting from Iran stopped in late December.

Agricultural production sank to record lows in 2021 and 2022, with wheat alone falling to a quarter of the around four million tonnes per year pre-war. Syria imported around one million tonnes of cereal annually from Russia. Ukraine has also signalled willingness to supply wheat.

title: Trump’s Shifting Tariffs Are Disrupting Global Shipping
content: The current situation off the U.S. West Coast, though, is causing plenty of suppressed ranting among seafarers and shipping lines. The United States may just have paused its 145 percent tariffs on ...
resumen: The United States may have paused its 145 percent tariffs on China, but U.S. President Donald Trump’s trade war is still sending shockwaves across the oceans. The United States and China agreed to pause their sky-high tariffs of 145 percent and 125 percent, respectively. For the next 90 days, the United States will impose 30 percent tariffs on goods coming from China, while China will impose 10 percent tariffs on U.S. goods. Shipping is at the forefront of every change in global trading. The U.S. accounts for almost 20% of containerized trade, primarily longhaul shipments from East Asia. U.S. imports from China suddenly became more than twice as expensive. The Port of Los Angeles forecast arrivals plummeting by one-third. When CNN checked arrivals at the Port of LA and the neighboring Port of Long Beach on May 9, the latter had seen arrival volumes plunge by 35-40 percent compared with normal volume, while arrivals at the Port of LA were down by 31 percent. Cargo ship departures from China to the United States had nearly halved. Port of LA Executive Director Gene Seroka said the volume coming out of China will be very light at best. The warning from dockworker representatives that the drop would cause layoffs was entirely unsurprising. Truckers were equally panicked. Chinese-made cargo bound for the United States was en route but hadn’t yet arrived when Trump imposed the tariffs. In China, exporters scrambled to find alternative buyers for their wares, primarily Europe or countries in Asia. Some U.S. importers deployed the “hope and prayer strategy,” storing their imports at port facilities. 30 percent U.S. tariffs (and 10 percent Chinese tariffs) are definitely preferable to 145 percent and 125 percent. Americans are just going to consume less, and the ship-booking data is irrefutable proof of that. The Houthis have made the crucial Red Sea and the Suez Canal virtually impassable for Western shipping lines, and the shadow fleet operated by Russia has grown so quickly that it now poses a real hazard to legally sailing ships. Shipping lines have adapted their journeys and procedures. They’ve rerouted from Suez to the Cape of Good Hope. They’re steering away from China-U.S. routes. Some routes will change, but the reality for most crews is either a longer period of not being paid or having to find alternative employment. For seafarers, it’s hard to find alternative employment at short notice. Lost assignments equate lost income. Seafarers who didn’t lose routes found their assignments and schedules changed. There’s a crewing crisis, and demand is still greater than supply. Shipping will be fine and is way ahead. Vessels have literally already been rerouted to maximize profit on more dependable routes. America’s ports and domestic businesses don’t have that luxury. The dockworker unions may be onto something with their warning of looming job losses. The shipping industry is likely to shift its focus to routes that don’t bring sudden, politically motivated turbulence.

title: La torta del Sr Trump en su plan de acción de gobierno
content: ¿QUE PASARIA CON LA OMC EN CASO DE SEGUIR ESTA LOCURA? Nos quedaríamos cortos, al pensar que el nuevo presidente de los EEUU, Sr Trump, no solo ha roto récords en los tres meses y 15 días que ...
resumen:
El nuevo presidente de los EEUU, Sr Trump, ha establecido propuestas unilaterales de anexiones del Canadá, como posible estado número 51 de la unión, la anexión de Groenlandia y la devolución del canal de Panamá a los EEUU. Sus acciones están convirtiendo el actual comercio mundial en una operación sin protocolos ni normas, lo que ha hecho posible el inicio de una debacle de la OMC (Organización Mundial del Comercio) y la posible inutilidad de la gestión reglamentaria de este organismo.

La guerra de aranceles utilizada por el Sr Trump, aplicada a la totalidad de los países del orbe, ha paralizado el movimiento comercial y busca el reacomodo de países emergentes como Rusia, China, India, Sur África, Brasil, Vietnam.

El Sr Trump está, posiblemente, dando marcha atrás con el caso de la locura sometida a RP China, al quizás comprender lo que sería, aplicar aranceles tan elevados como 125% advalorem a este país.

Las actitudes del Sr Trump semejan una bofetada a la comunidad internacional, para intentar poner de rodillas a los países y después redefinir acuerdos, creando incertidumbre y un acelerado proceso inflacionario en su propio país.

Se aplica una presión que va desde un cerco real o bloqueo, hasta la congelación de dinero en bancos alrededor del mundo, la confiscación de activos, como es el caso de CITGO.

Las medidas coercitivas unilaterales han impactado en la economía venezolana en algo más de 70%.

La idea es tratar de doblegar por la fuerza a la nación objetivo, he intentar derrocar a los gobiernos que ya tengan un plan de desarrollo económico y social a buen rumbo, como es el caso de las 7 (T) o transformaciones que adelanta el gobierno nacional para los próximos 6 años.

Los migrantes del año 2015 en adelante, al ser sometida la población venezolana al impacto de las medidas coercitivas unilaterales, se dedicó a la sedición y a la perturbación de las actividades cotidianas.

El secretario de estado de los EEUU, Sr Maikel Pompeo, el Sr Abrams y el EX embajador de USA en Venezuela William Bronsfield, se preciaban de exponer por los medios de comunicación de aplicar medidas que hicieran posible crear un ambiente de crisis nacional para obligar a salir la población de manera desesperada de Venezuela hacia otros países y en la práctica para los EEUU, vía Colombia- Selva de Darién.

title: As Ontario faces economic uncertainty, experts outline budget wish list
content: Premier Doug Ford's government is set to unveil its 2025 Ontario budget later this afternoon, against the backdrop of an escalating US trade war, economic uncertainty and mounting anxiety over ...
resumen:
Premier Doug Ford’s government is set to unveil its 2025 Ontario budget later this afternoon, against the backdrop of an escalating US trade war, economic uncertainty and mounting anxiety over the future of the province’s auto sector.

The Financial Accountability Office (FAO) warned that up to 68,100 jobs could be lost this year due to trade disruptions, with the toll rising to 137,900 by 2029 if tensions continue.

With 85 per cent of Ontario exports going to the US, and the auto sector contributing $36 billion to the province’s $220-billion export economy, Ontario’s economic future depends on how the government responds.

This will be Ford’s first budget since winning a third majority, and it’s expected to outline how his government plans to address growing economic uncertainty caused by US tariffs.

The province’s finance minister, Peter Bethlenfalvy, warned that Ontario is facing “a challenge unlike anything we have ever faced before,” due to US tariffs.

Bethlenfalvy said the upcoming budget will focus on affordability and economic protection.

Bethlenfalvy said the 2025 budget will be “a plan to protect Ontario,” outlining how the government will take decisive action to grow the province’s economy, lower costs for families, and support workers and businesses.

The province has already rolled out an $11-billion package in response to tariffs that includes deferred tax payments, a $1-billion boost to its skills development fund, and rebates for employers through the Workplace Safety and Insurance Board (WSIB).

Mahmood Nanji, a policy fellow at Western University’s Ivey Business School and former Ontario associate deputy finance minister, said the government must tread carefully.

Nanji said the Ford government should take a cautious approach to its growth projections and fiscal planning.

Nanji also highlighted the importance of targeted support for workers and communities affected by economic disruptions — Ontario should support small- and medium-sized businesses in accessing new markets, including through trade missions and federal partnerships.

He urged the Ford government to focus on long-term productivity and seize new opportunities to work with Carney’s government on housing, infrastructure, clean energy and high-speed rail — as well as key investments like the Ring of Fire, nuclear energy expansion, and skilled trades training.

Sheldon Williamson, a professor at Ontario Tech University and Canada Research Chair in electric energy storage systems, said the budget needs to send a signal of strategic support for the EV sector and broader manufacturing sectors, and support innovation.

Williamson said Ontario must boost its competitiveness through incentives for advanced manufacturing and research, especially in areas hit hardest by job losses.

Strengthening infrastructure — such as energy, transportation, and digital systems — should also be a key priority.

Nanji suggested the 2025 budget is unlikely to include significant climate action.

The NDP, Liberals, and Greens are calling for major investments in healthcare, housing and education, as well as stronger protections for workers and industries hit by tariffs.

title: Walmart subirá los precios por aranceles: ¿qué productos impactará?
content: Los aranceles incrementarán los precios de algunos productos de Walmart, como aparatos electrónicos, juguetes y algunos alimentos ...
resumen: Walmart subirá los precios por aranceles. Los aranceles impuestos por el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, afectarán a aparatos electrónicos, juguetes y algunos alimentos importados de varios países. Walmart es una de las principales cadenas de supermercados en Estados Unidos y América Latina. John David Rainey, director financiero de Walmart, indicó que algunos productos ya han comenzado a subir sus precios. Los proveedores han subido el precio de alimentos como el plátano a 54 centavos la libra, cuando anteriormente estaba a 50 centavos. Doug McMillon, director general de Walmart, resaltó que, además del plátano, productos como el aguacate, el café y las rosas han subido su precio tras los aranceles de Estados Unidos a las importaciones provenientes de Costa Rica, Perú y Colombia. Los consumidores probablemente verán aumentos de precios en productos alimenticios que no se producen, o se producen en cantidades muy pequeñas, en Estados Unidos, como plátanos, café y aceite de oliva. Productos importados de Canadá a Estados Unidos que aumentarán de precio: madera, carbón, aluminio, electrodomésticos de hierro y acero, cereales, harinas y almidones, productos lácteos, goma, bebidas alcohólicas, alfombras y otros revestimientos textiles para suelos, lana, pelo animal, hilo y crin de caballo, paraguas, bastones, bastones de asiento, látigos, algodón, productos fotográficos o cinematográficos, productos de corcho, libros impresos. Productos importados de México a Estados Unidos que aumentarán de precio: cereales, productos de papel, frutas y frutos secos procesados, frutas tropicales, tomates, cebollas, lechuga y repollo, alimentos encurtidos, jugos de frutas, fertilizantes, productos lácteos, huevos, miel, algodón, cerveza y licores, café, té, mate y especias, carne, pescado y mariscos, salsas y condimentos, productos horneados, aguacates, azúcar en bruto. Productos importados de China a Estados Unidos que aumentarán de precio: pescados y mariscos, aceites y grasas vegetales, verduras, frutas y frutos secos, maíz, jabones, lubricantes, ceras, velas, pastas para modelar, cereales, harinas, almidones y trigo, productos lácteos, café, té y especias, azúcar, cacao, huevos, miel, vinagre, zumo de manzana, ajo. Los aranceles son impuestos que gravan la importación de bienes. El presidente Donald Trump ha declarado que los aranceles son un componente clave de su estrategia económica.

title: Walmart anuncia que subirá precios por aranceles tras sólidos resultados del primer trimestre
content: Las ganancias del primer trimestre de Walmart disminuyeron, y la compañía anunció que debe aumentar los precios debido a los costos más altos por los aranceles implementados por el presidente Donald T ...
resumen:
Las ganancias del primer trimestre de Walmart disminuyeron. La compañía anunció que debe aumentar los precios debido a los costos más altos por los aranceles implementados por el presidente Donald Trump.

El mayor minorista del país reportó fuertes ventas trimestrales e indicó que espera un crecimiento de ventas del 3.5% al 4.5% en el segundo trimestre del año.

Walmart mantuvo su guía para todo el año emitida en febrero.

Los datos del gobierno revelaron un crecimiento de ventas más lento para los minoristas el jueves. Walmart afirmó que sus consumidores siguen siendo cautelosos y selectivos.

Los aranceles de Trump sobre China y otros países amenazan el modelo de precios bajos que es fundamental para el éxito de Walmart.

Los impuestos de importación amenazados por Trump del 145% sobre los productos chinos se redujeron al 30% en un acuerdo anunciado el lunes, con algunos de los aranceles más altos en pausa durante 90 días.

Muchos minoristas sostienen que deben aumentar los precios debido a los costos de los aranceles. Y también se están preparando para costos de envío más altos.

Walmart ha establecido coberturas contra algunas amenazas arancelarias. Dos tercios de la mercancía de Walmart se obtiene en Estados Unidos, con los comestibles impulsando gran parte de eso. Los comestibles representan aproximadamente el 60% del negocio de Walmart en Estados Unidos.

El CEO de Walmart, Doug McMillon, dijo que no pueden absorber toda la presión ante la realidad de los márgenes minoristas estrechos.

Los aumentos de precios en los estantes serán graduales, pero ya habían comenzado desde abril, y se aceleraron en mayo. La compañía dijo que se ha centrado en los recibos de regreso a clases.

McMillon afirmó que importa mercancía general de todo el mundo desde docenas de países. Pero China, en particular, representa una gran parte del volumen en ciertas categorías como electrónica y juguetes.

Los aranceles sobre países como Costa Rica, Perú y Colombia están aumentando los costos de comestibles como bananas, aguacates, café y rosas.

Walmart está absorbiendo costos en mercancía general dentro de los departamentos y aún no está trasladando los costos crecientes en algunos casos.

Walmart también está pidiendo a los proveedores que cambien los materiales de entrada para los componentes, por ejemplo, usando fibra de vidrio en lugar de aluminio, al que Trump impuso aranceles a principios de marzo.

Walmart ganó $4,450 millones de dólares, o 56 centavos por acción, en el trimestre que terminó el 30 de abril, por debajo de los $5,100 millones de dólares, o 63 centavos por acción, en el mismo período del año pasado.

Las ganancias ajustadas por acción fueron de 61 centavos de dólar, superando las proyecciones de 58 centavos de los analistas de la industria, según FactSet.

Los ingresos aumentaron un 2.5% a $65,610 millones de dólares, apenas por debajo de las estimaciones de los analistas.

Las ventas comparables de Walmart en Estados Unidos aumentaron un 4.5% en el segundo trimestre, aunque eso se desaceleró desde un aumento del 4.6% en el trimestre anterior y un incremento del 5.3% en el tercer trimestre de 2024.

Las acciones cayeron un 4% al toque de la campana de apertura el jueves.

El negocio fue impulsado por artículos de salud y bienestar, así como comestibles. Las ventas fueron más débiles en artículos para el hogar y deportivos, lo cual fue compensado por robustas ventas de juguetes, productos automotrices y ropa infantil.

Las ventas globales de comercio electrónico aumentaron un 22%, frente al 16% en el trimestre anterior.

Amazon anunció mayores ganancias y ventas en el primer trimestre.

title: Walmart confirma: así golpean los aranceles de Donald Trump las exportaciones de Costa Rica
content: Walmart señaló cómo las políticas arancelarias implementadas por Donald Trump están impactando las exportaciones desde Costa Rica.
resumen:
Walmart, durante la presentación de sus resultados trimestrales en Estados Unidos, señaló que las políticas arancelarias implementadas durante la administración de Donald Trump están encareciendo productos clave importados desde Costa Rica, afectando las exportaciones del país y los precios para el consumidor estadounidense.

Doug McMillon, director general de Walmart, detalló que los aranceles impuestos por Estados Unidos a las importaciones provenientes de Costa Rica, Perú y Colombia, han provocado un aumento en el costo de productos como bananos, aguacates, café y rosas.

McMillon afirmó que harán todo lo posible para mantener los precios bajos, pero advirtió que no son capaces de absorber toda la presión inflacionaria debido a la magnitud de los aranceles.

Walmart reportó ganancias de 4.500 millones de dólares, un descenso del 12,1% en comparación con el año anterior, pero superando las expectativas de los analistas. Los ingresos generales de la compañía aumentaron un 2,5%, alcanzando los 165.600 millones de dólares, con un crecimiento del 4,5% en las ventas comparables de sus tiendas en Estados Unidos.

La Corporación Bananera Nacional (Corbana) emitió un comunicado en el que niega que las exportaciones de banano se verán afectadas de “manera sustancial” por el arancel impuesto por Estados Unidos.

Corbana reaccionó a un informe del Centro Internacional de Política Económica para el Desarrollo Sostenible (Cinpe) de una Universidad Nacional en donde se estima que las exportaciones podrían caer un 18% por un efecto de sustitución.

Según Corbana, Ecuador, el otro gran proveedor de banano a Estados Unidos, también estará sometido a un arancel recíproco del 10%.

La dirección de Walmart indicó que, si bien recibieron con agrado una reciente distensión en la guerra comercial entre Estados Unidos y China, los impuestos aduaneros que permanecen en vigor continúan siendo elevados y generan incertidumbre.

Estos aranceles afectan a productos agrícolas de Latinoamérica, así como a categorías como aparatos electrónicos y juguetes.

title: Trump says he had a 'little problem with Tim Cook' over Apple's India expansion
content: The president said he doesn't want Apple to shift its production to India. The iPhone maker is grappling with tough tariff measures on China.
resumen: President Donald Trump said he doesn't want Apple to build in India. President Donald Trump has a "little problem with Tim Cook." Speaking in Qatar, the president said he recently told the Apple CEO that he doesn't want the iPhone maker to shift its manufacturing production to India. Apple has long depended on a vast supply chain empire in China. Apple has taken measures to diversify its operations away from China. The company also committed in February to investing $500 billion in the US over the next four years. "I had a little problem with Tim Cook yesterday," Trump said Thursday. "I said to him, 'Tim, you're my friend. I've treated you very good. You're coming here with $500 billion, but now I hear you're building all over India. I don't want you building in India.'" The company has spent recent years deepening its ties to India, where it has ramped up iPhone production. Apple largely works with the Taiwanese firm Foxconn to assemble its iPhones in India and has partnerships with the local firm Tata, too. Trump made clear he didn't want Cook to put more operations in India after "we've put up with all the plants that you built in China for years." "You can build in India if you want to take care of India," Trump added. Trump said that Apple would be "upping their production in the United States."

title: Trump is pushing the EU and China closer. Is this a full reset, or just strategic readjustment?
content: The EU and China have, historically, had a complex relationship. This was encapsulated in the European Commission’s 2019 EU-China strategic outlook, which referred to China as both a “strategic ...
resumen:
The EU and China have historically had a complex relationship, described in the European Commission’s 2019 EU-China strategic outlook as both a “strategic partner”, but also an “economic competitor” and “systemic rival promoting alternative models of governance”. Tensions have increased since then, with disagreements over China’s responsibility for the origin of the COVID pandemic and China’s position on the war in Ukraine. Donald Trump’s potential return to the White House could lead to a rapprochement between the EU and China to resist Washington’s trade policies.

The EU’s pursuit of renewed relations with China has been ongoing for at least two years, with Ursula von der Leyen and Emmanuel Macron traveling to China in April 2023 with the goal of a “reset” in relations. A strategy of rebalancing towards China vis-à-vis the US was already being weighed up by the European Union as far back as 2017, during the first Trump Administration.

China regards the EU as weak and divided and believes that a few declarations and symbolic gestures will be enough to send the EU into China’s waiting arms. China appointed Lu Shaye, known for his tough “wolf warrior” style of diplomacy, as Special Envoy for Relations with Europe.

For Brussels, issues preventing a clean slate in relations with China include the close ties between Beijing and Moscow, bolstered by Xi Jinping’s recent attendance at Russia’s Victory Day military parade on May 9. China’s contribution to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is another obstacle. High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Kaja Kallas, has stated that “China is the key enabler of Russia’s war”.

Brussels ought to take a pragmatic and calculated approach that allows it to compensate for the problems arising from the Trump administration’s trade policy, but without renouncing its values and interests. The European Union remains aware of the risks associated with Chinese investment in strategic and high-tech sectors, as well as of the risks associated with those sectors and activities which could endanger data protection. The EU is seeing a tactical adjustment, introducing a relaxation of language and building a relationship that grants the EU more options and room for manoeuvre in its dealings with the US, without abandoning the logic of derisking in the continent’s relationship to China.

title: Money blog: New Rightmove mortgage tool could have 'dangerous' consequences
content: Welcome to the Money blog, Sky News' consumer and personal finance hub. Today: we're reporting on official GDP data showing UK economic growth in the first three months of 2025.
resumen:
*   A new online mortgage lender tool could have "dangerous" consequences, brokers have warned.
*   Rightmove and Nationwide have teamed up to launch the "property lender check", which gives potential buyers real-time information about their chances of getting a mortgage approved for a property before they view it or put in an offer.
*   Brokers have raised concerns that the tool only uses the lending criteria used by Nationwide.
*   Craig Fish, director at Lodestone Mortgages & Protection, said it could lead to buyers being "wrongly put off perfectly good homes".
*   Fish called it "potentially a dangerous" move.
*   Stephen Perkins, managing director at Yellow Brick Mortgages, questioned if it could lead to legal challenges being raised.

title: Los 100 días de Trump y el unilateralismo agresivo de EU
content: Del 20 de enero al 29 de abril –con 142 órdenes ejecutivas firmadas y la aplicación de políticas arancelarias al margen de la ley–, la administración de Donald Trump ha administrado el declive hegemón ...
resumen: Del 20 de enero al 29 de abril, la administración de Donald Trump ha administrado el declive hegemónico de Estados Unidos, con 142 órdenes ejecutivas firmadas y la aplicación de políticas arancelarias. Trump busca posicionar a Estados Unidos mediante el programa America First y el control geopolítico de océanos, mares, rutas comerciales y recursos. La política de sanciones económicas es una estrategia de reposicionamiento comercial ante el avance de China y otros países. México aparece en la posición nueve de las principales economías del mundo. El gobierno de Trump realizará una revisión de cualquier práctica desleal de otros países y se inició el proceso de consulta pública para revisar el T-MEC. La apuesta no es por los grandes acuerdos comerciales, sino por acuerdos bilaterales o sectoriales, así como la revisión de los ya firmados, incluyendo a México. La imposición de sanciones económicas (aranceles) al mundo excluyó al T-MEC.  La guerra comercial inició con Trump en 2017 y fue continuada por Biden en 2021, incluyendo estrategias de seguridad nacional. En mayo, el secretario de Estado Marco Rubio se reunió con países del Caribe Oriental y las Bahamas para actualizar la Iniciativa de Seguridad de la Cuenca del Caribe, abordando temas como seguridad fronteriza, migración y trasiego ilegal de armas y drogas. A 100 días de iniciado el segundo mandato de Trump, la Ley de Poderes Económicos fue usada por primera vez para imponer aranceles y ya tiene algunas demandas en contra de una docena de estados de EU. Trump critica la guerra en Ucrania y declaró que [Vladimir Putin] “deje de disparar, se siente y firme un acuerdo”.  Estados Unidos busca que Rusia conserve la mayor parte de los territorios conquistados en Ucrania, preponderantemente la estratégica isla de Crimea.  Desde 2022 y hasta 2025 se han perdido 150 mil millones de dólares sólo en infraestructura física en Ucrania. Se han congelado 300 mil millones en activos rusos. Se estima que la reconstrucción costará 750 mil millones de dólares. Ucrania pone a disposición de EU los minerales disponibles: oro, cobre, litio, uranio, grafito, titanio.  El plan de reconstrucción y el fin de la guerra puede ser interpretada como una necesidad económica y estratégica de controlar y explotar la gran cantidad de recursos y mano de obra disponible en Ucrania.  Si Rusia se queda con la región del Donbas, supondría el control de carbón, gas y petróleo con un valor estimado de 12.5 mil millones de dólares. Trump aplica el unilateralismo agresivo, amenazando al mundo con sanciones económicas, saliendo de organizaciones multilaterales, firmando acuerdos lesivos para otros países, repartiendo y apropiándose de recursos estratégicos y definiendo a los migrantes como sujetos narco-terroristas.  Estados Unidos incrementó su producción de petróleo y gas hasta convertirse en el primer productor internacional. En 2024 promedió una producción de 13.2 millones de barriles diarios de petróleo y 113 mil millones de pies cúbicos por día de gas.  Las principales estrategias son: Camino hacia la prosperidad de las Américas (2008); Connecting the Americas 2022 (2012); Cooperación EE.UU.- Australia (2016); Formalizar la estrategia Indo-Pacífico (2019); US-Caribbean Strategy (2020); Formalizar el AUKUS con Australia, Gran Bretaña (2021); Estrategia de Protección Energética con Europa (2021).  Se suma la creación del Consejo Nacional de Dominio Energético. China puso restricciones a la exportación a EU de germanio, galio y antimonio, minerales estratégicos. El Departamento de Estado sintetizó los principales logros del gobierno de Donald Trump: Cumplir una política exterior de “America First”, asegurar relaciones comerciales económicamente justas, restaurar el liderazgo de EE. UU., frenar la inmigración ilegal y el fentanilo, combatir a nuestros adversarios y promover una paz duradera.  Desde que entró Donald Trump a la presidencia, mencionó recuperar el Canal de Panamá y comprar Groenlandia. El Comando Sur se reunió con el presidente Javier Milei y miembros de las fuerzas armadas argentinas para fortalecer la cooperación bilateral en defensa y seguridad. Argentina continua la compra-venta de sus recursos estratégicos entre los que destacan el litio, cobre, pero también el gas del mega-yacimiento Vaca Muerta.  En las últimas administraciones estadunidenses hay un largo ciclo conservador en el que la estrategia de reposicionamiento implica un muro de hierro con estrategias militares en el Atlántico, pero también la conformación de un polígono de seguridad en el Pacífico, al que se suma el aseguramiento de los polos; la guerra comercial y el uso de sus leyes con aplicación extraterritorial para imponer sanciones económicas con el objetivo de abatir su déficit comercial y reordenar el comercio mundial.

title: Trump administration’s first months bring mixed reaction from Imperial County officials
content: County leaders are grappling with Trump’s executive orders and the priorities of GOP lawmakers ahead of the county’s annual budget talks.
resumen:
En su reunión regular del martes, la Junta de Supervisores del condado, de cinco miembros, se reunió con los cabilderos de Paragon Governmental Relations, la firma que impulsa las prioridades del condado en Washington. Discutieron los últimos movimientos del gobierno federal antes de las próximas conversaciones anuales sobre el presupuesto del condado.

Por un lado, los líderes del condado se mostraron optimistas sobre los anuncios de la Casa Blanca sobre el aumento de la producción de minerales críticos en los EE. UU. Lo ven como una oportunidad para destacar las vastas reservas de litio del Valle Imperial, que muchos esperan que transformen la región en un centro nacional de tecnología de baterías.

Por otro lado, algunos funcionarios del condado están preocupados por los amplios recortes que los miembros republicanos del Congreso han propuesto para programas federales como Medicaid, el plan de atención médica de bajo costo de la nación, y el Programa de Asistencia Nutricional Suplementaria (SNAP), que ayuda a las personas a pagar productos frescos y otros comestibles.

Muchos residentes del condado de Imperial dependen de los dos programas, que se conocen como Medi-Cal y Calfresh en California. Más de la mitad de los residentes del condado tienen seguro médico a través de Medi-Cal, según el Centro Laboral de la UC Berkeley, y el 27% de los residentes reciben ayuda de Calfresh.

El supervisor Jesús Eduardo Escobar también expresó su preocupación por los impactos de la represión de la inmigración de la Casa Blanca. Específicamente, les preocupa que pueda estar restringiendo los cruces fronterizos entre Mexicali y Calexico y limitando el número de personas que compran bienes y pagan impuestos sobre las ventas en el condado de Imperial.

Joe Krahn, que trabaja para la firma de cabildeo del condado, Paragon Government Relations, dijo que habían hecho una prioridad rechazar los recortes a Medicaid y SNAP en el Congreso.

Hasan Sarsour, otro cabildero de Paragon, dijo que la firma estaba entusiasmada con el apoyo de la Casa Blanca a la industria del litio del condado. Sarsour dijo que se habían reunido varias veces con el Departamento de Energía y la Oficina de Asuntos Intergubernamentales de la Casa Blanca.

Paragon cabildea para varios clientes en el Congreso, incluidos varios otros gobiernos de condados de California.

La discusión se produce cuando los líderes del condado también se están preparando para sus conversaciones presupuestarias anuales.

El presupuesto del condado de Imperial ha crecido constantemente en los últimos años. El año pasado, los supervisores aprobaron un presupuesto de $749 millones. El condado también tenía casi $20 millones en fondos de reserva a partir del año pasado, según los documentos presupuestarios.

Los presupuestos del condado se adoptan típicamente antes del 30 de junio, aunque la ley estatal permite a los condados retrasar una votación final del presupuesto hasta el 2 de octubre. El año pasado, el condado de Imperial publicó su presupuesto propuesto a mediados de junio y adoptó un presupuesto final en septiembre.

title: Global shares rise, dollar softens amid tariff truce
content: Global shares and Wall Street were higher on an easing in trade tensions between the world’s two largest economies, while the US dollar extended losses ...
resumen:
Global shares and Wall Street were higher on an easing in trade tensions between the world’s two largest economies, while the US dollar extended losses as benign US inflation data kept Federal Reserve rate cuts on the table.

Gold prices fell as the US-China trade truce dimmed bullion’s safe-haven appeal.

European stocks eased after four sessions of gains.

Asian shares gained.

MSCI’s gauge of stocks across the globe rose 2.24 points, or 0.26%, to 873.44.

As a truce in the tariff spat between China and the United States appeared to hit pause in the global trade war, investors have pushed global equities higher, although European shares took a breather on Wednesday.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 64.35 points, or 0.15%, to 42,204.78, the S&P 500 rose 2.26 points, or 0.04%, to 5,888.81 and the Nasdaq Composite rose 72.27 points, or 0.38%, to 19,082.35.

Europe’s STOXX 600 retreated after having jumped over 17% since its trough on April 9, the day US President Donald Trump announced he would be pausing most of the reciprocal tariffs on US trading partners.

MSCI’s broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan closed higher by 1.56%, to 614.33, while Japan’s Nikkei fell 55.13 points, or 0.14%, to 38,128.13.

The broader Topix snapped a 13-day winning run, its longest streak in nearly 16 years.

Hong Kong’s Hang Seng index jumped, lifted by tech stocks after Chinese e-commerce retailer JD.com posted strong results.

Tencent, China’s biggest tech company, posted a 13% rise in first-quarter revenue on Wednesday.

Focus this week will also be on earnings from Alibaba on Thursday.

Data on Tuesday showing softer-than-expected US consumer inflation also provided some relief to investors worried about the inflationary impact of US tariff policies, which had severely undercut expectations of near-term Fed rate cuts.

The US tariffs on Chinese goods are still much higher than they were months ago.

Trump in an interview on Tuesday said he could see himself dealing directly with Chinese President Xi Jinping on details of a trade pact.

His touted “potential deals” with India, Japan and South Korea are still pending.

The Fed has warned of rising economic uncertainty, signalling it is prepared to wait to assess the impact of US tariffs before moving to cut interest rates again.

Fed Chair Jerome Powell is scheduled to give remarks on Thursday.

The US dollar fell 0.24% against a basket of currencies including the yen and the euro.

Global asset managers held their biggest underweight position in the dollar in 19 years in May, as Trump’s trade policy cut investor appetite for US assets, Bank of America’s global fund manager survey (FMS) showed on Tuesday.

The euro gained 0.25% to $1.1212.

US yields rose as investors weighed softer-than-expected April inflation data against expectations that tariffs will fuel higher prices in the coming months.

Eurozone yields meanwhile retreated.

The next major signal for US economic health is retail sales data for April due on Thursday.

In commodities, rising US crude stockpiles pressured prices.

Brent crude futures fell to $66.07 per barrel, down 0.84% on the day.

US crude fell 0.91% to $63.09 a barrel.

Spot gold fell 1.96% to $3,183.69 an ounce.

Canada’s main stock index fell on Wednesday, after six straight sessions of gains.

The Toronto Stock Exchange’s S&P/TSX composite index was down 0.13% at 25,583.02 points after rising 2.6% in the past six sessions and hitting a three-month high last week.

title: Tech and Trade Tensions Rise Amid US Restrictions on Huawei Chips
content: The US has implemented new rules restricting the use of Huawei's Ascend chips globally, citing export control violations, prompting criticism from China. Despite lifting some retaliatory measures, ...
resumen: The US has implemented new rules restricting the use of Huawei's Ascend chips globally, citing export control violations, prompting criticism from China. Despite lifting some retaliatory measures, trade tensions persist between the US and China, especially concerning tariffs and cooperation in high-tech industries. The United States has introduced new limitations on Huawei Technologies by imposing restrictions on the global usage of the Ascend computer chips, sparking backlash from China. The move is perceived as a part of ongoing trade tensions between the world's two largest economies. While China has announced the lifting of certain retaliatory measures, such as the ban on exporting rare earth minerals to the US, mutual frictions remain. The US Commerce Department insists that Huawei's semiconductors infringe on export controls due to their purported use of American technology. China's Commerce Ministry has urged the US to amend its 'erroneous practices', emphasizing their unhelpful nature for long-term cooperation. The continued US tariffs on Chinese steel and aluminum exacerbate the issue, with China calling for an end to these levies, especially under Sections 232 and 301.

title: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon warns recession still possible: ‘I wouldn’t take it off the table’
content: Financial markets continue to absorb the ripple effects of the Trump administration’s sweeping tariff policies.
resumen:
JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon is warning that a recession remains a real possibility.
Dimon told Bloomberg Television on Thursday during JPMorgan’s Global Markets Conference in Paris: “Hopefully we’ll avoid it, but I wouldn’t take it off the table at this point.”
“If there is a recession, I don’t know how big it would be or how long it would last.”
Dimon’s comments come amid ongoing uncertainty sparked by President Trump’s “Liberation Day” announcement of tariffs on dozens of countries, followed days later by a 90-day pause to pursue trade agreements.
The back-and-forth has jolted markets, and Dimon said some JPMorgan clients are already putting investment plans on hold due to the volatility.
Dimon said of the trade war, adding that he hopes the recent cooling of tensions between the US and China leads to productive negotiations.
Dimon has been vocal about the need for a stable trade framework and has urged the Trump administration to empower Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent to lead talks with foreign governments.
In his recent shareholder letter, he pressed for a swift resolution, warning that prolonged uncertainty would dampen economic growth.
Dimon noted that JPMorgan has benefited from recent market swings.
JPMorgan Chase, the nation’s largest lender with nearly $4 trillion in assets under management, generated record revenue in the first quarter, and analysts anticipate another strong showing in the second quarter — even before the full impact of the April tariffs takes hold.
Dimon also cautioned that global sentiment toward the US may be fraying.
Dimon said, pointing to anecdotal backlash.
Still, he remains bullish on America’s long-term prospects.
Billionaire investor and Mets owner Steve Cohen offered a slightly more cautious outlook, estimating the chance of a US recession at 45%.
Cohen, founder of the hedge fund Point72 Asset Management, said during the Sohn Investment Conference in New York on Wednesday.
Cohen predicted that US GDP could slow to 1.5% or lower next year and said the Federal Reserve is unlikely to cut interest rates in the near term because “they are going to be worried about inflation from tariffs.”
Point72 posted a 2.3% gain in April, pushing its year-to-date return to 3%, Bloomberg previously reported.

title: APEC warns of stalling trade due to tariffs as China, US officials meet
content: The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) grouping warned on Thursday that exports from a region that accounts for around half of world trade will ...
resumen: The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) grouping warned that exports from a region that accounts for around half of world trade will slow sharply this year, and barely grow at all, in the wake of U.S. tariff announcements. APEC projected exports in the region would rise by only 0.4% this year, compared with 5.7% growth last year. The bloc also cut its regional economic growth forecast for this year to 2.6% from 3.3% previously. APEC said trade growth is set to decline sharply across APEC due to lower external demand, particularly in manufacturing and consumer goods, while rising uncertainty over goods-related measures weighs on services trade. U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer met Chinese trade envoy Li Chenggang on the sidelines of the gathering. Greer and Li agreed to slash steep tariffs at their first face-to-face talks in Geneva on May 10-11. South Korea Trade Minister Cheong highlighted how the global economy and trade face added strain from uncertainties and urged the bloc to foster dialogue to tackle political and economic challenges. APEC policy director, Carlos Kuriyama, attributed the downgrading of the regional export outlook to the impact of U.S. tariffs. Greer is also scheduled to hold a bilateral meeting with his South Korean counterpart, three weeks after their opening round of trade talks in Washington, D.C. He will also have his first face-to-face meeting with New Zealand and meet with representatives from other Asian countries. Greer was also expected to meet the heads of South Korean shipbuilders HD Hyundai Heavy Industries and Hanwha Ocean. The APEC gathering is being attended by trade ministers and envoys from member countries including Japan, Canada, Mexico and Russia. Cheong said he held a meeting with China’s Li, who explained Beijing’s commitment to supporting the multilateral trade regime and global supply chain. The trade ministers’ meeting is being held as part of a second round of senior officials’ meetings ahead of an APEC leaders’ summit this year in Gyeongju, South Korea. APEC accounts for about half of global trade and 60% of global GDP.

title: Gold tumbles on US-China trade truce
content: Gold has sold off this week following the de-escalation in the global trade war. Meanwhile, ETF and central bank gold buying is easing. Is gold losing its momentum? Gold tumbles o ...
resumen:
Gold has sold off this week following the de-escalation in the global trade war. ETF and central bank gold buying is easing. Gold prices have dropped more than 3% so far this week to their lowest in more than a month. Gold is still up by more than 20% this year, after peaking at a record $3,500/oz in April. The global trade war, geopolitical risks and central bank buying were the key drivers for the precious metal’s rally.
The US and China agreed to temporarily reduce tariffs on each other’s goods. The US slashing duties on Chinese products to 30% from 145% for a 90-day period, while Beijing reduced its levy on most goods to 10%. China also suspended a ban on exports of items with both military and civil applications to 28 US companies, as well as a trade and investment ban against 17 US companies.
US Secretary of the Treasury Scott Bessent later said it is “implausible” that reciprocal tariffs on China go below 10%, but the 2 April level – set by the President at 34% – “would be a ceiling”. Trump said tariffs could go higher again if the two countries fail to reach an agreement.
US inflation figures for April were softer-than-expected. Traders now see at least two rate reductions this year, with the first likely in September.
ETF buying has been cooling off since late April.
The first quarter of the year saw a sharp revival in ETF inflows – marking the strongest quarter since 1Q22.
Central bank buying has started to ease. In the first quarter, central banks bought 244 tonnes of gold, down 33% from the previous quarter.
China’s central bank expanded its gold reserves for the sixth consecutive month, by 2.2 tonnes in April, lifting the total to 2,295 tonnes, or 6.8% of overall reserve assets. So far in 2025, China has announced an increase of 14.9 tonnes in its official gold holdings.
In the past six months, volumes have climbed by about 30 tonnes.
Last year, central banks bought a combined 1,045 tonnes. Poland, India and Turkey were the largest buyers in 2024, according to the World Gold Council.
Gold prices are expected to average $3,250/oz in the second quarter. An average of $3,128/oz is expected in 2025.

title: República Dominicana y Bahamas identifican oportunidades de inversión y comercio
content: Santo Domingo, 15 may (EFE).- La República Dominicana y Bahamas identificaron oportunidades de inversión y comercio, durante una reunión este jueves de sus cancilleres Roberto Álvarez y Frederick Mitc ...
resumen: La República Dominicana y Bahamas identificaron oportunidades de inversión y comercio, durante una reunión este jueves de sus cancilleres Roberto Álvarez y Frederick Mitchell, respectivamente. Mitchell manifestó el interés de Bahamas de identificar mercados más accesibles para importar productos agropecuarios y otras mercancías a su país y República Dominicana es una gran oportunidad para ello. Ambos cancilleres y sus comitivas conversaron además sobre iniciativas para fomentar el turismo sostenible, facilitar la conectividad aérea y marítima en el Caribe, y promover espacios de formación y capacitación técnica en beneficio de los jóvenes de ambos países. Álvarez comentó a su homólogo bahameño que la X Cumbre de las Américas, que se celebrará en el país a finales de este año, concentrará en el Foro Empresarial, a los principales ejecutivos de las empresas más importantes del hemisferio y por ende será un gran espacio para expandir el mercado de sus países. La presencia del canciller bahameño representa una oportunidad para explorar áreas de cooperación económica, en especial en sectores donde ambos países pueden complementarse, al fomentar un diálogo que permita identificar nichos de intercambio comercial. La visita busca impulsar el acercamiento entre empresarios y fortalecer la presencia de productos dominicanos en el mercado bahameño, en línea con los objetivos de la política exterior del país de promover el comercio y la inversión.

title: Presidente Xi Jinping asiste a la inauguración de Celac y pronuncia una intervención principal
content: El Presidente Xi Jinping anunció la puesta en marcha de cinco programas entre China y América Latina y el Caribe (ALC).
resumen: El Presidente Xi Jinping asistió a la Inauguración de la Cuarta Reunión Ministerial del Foro China-Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribeños (Celac) el 13 de mayo en el Centro Nacional de Convenciones y pronunció una intervención principal. El Presidente Xi Jinping anunció la puesta en marcha de cinco programas entre China y América Latina y el Caribe (ALC), a fin de planificar juntos para el desarrollo y la revitalización y construir juntos la comunidad de futuro compartido China-ALC. El Presidente Xi Jinping, el presidente de Colombia y presidente Pro Tempore de la Celac Gustavo Petro, el presidente de Brasil Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, el presidente de Chile Gabriel Boric y jefes de las delegaciones de países y organizaciones regionales se estrecharon cordialmente las manos y tomaron una foto colectiva. El presidente Xi Jinping señaló que, en 2015, él y representantes de los países de la región, asistieron a la Inauguración de la Primera Reunión Ministerial del Foro China-Celac (FCC) en Beijing, lo que marcó el lanzamiento del FCC. China y ALC ya son una comunidad de futuro compartido que avanza de la mano y que tiene el trato en pie de igualdad como su carácter definitorio, los beneficios mutuos y las ganancias compartidas como su fuerte impulso, la apertura y la inclusión como su visión y cualidad, y el bienestar para los pueblos como su propósito fundamental. China está dispuesta a trabajar junto con ALC para emprender cinco programas: el programa de la solidaridad, el programa del desarrollo, el programa de las civilizaciones, el programa de la paz y el programa de los pueblos. En los próximos tres años, China invitará anualmente a 300 cuadros de partidos políticos de los países miembros de la CELAC a visitar China. China importará más productos de calidad desde ALC, y animará a sus empresas a aumentar las inversiones en ALC. China va a proporcionar a los países miembros de la Celac 3 mil 500 becas gubernamentales, 10 mil oportunidades de formación en China, 500 becas para profesores internacionales del idioma chino, 300 oportunidades de formación para profesionales en reducción de la pobreza, y mil plazas de visita a China en el marco de “Puente Chino”, ejecutar 300 proyectos de bienestar “pequeños y hermosos”, y apoyar a los países miembros de la Celac a desarrollar la enseñanza del idioma chino. China aplicará la política de exención de visas para cinco países de ALC como primer paso para luego ampliar su cobertura a países de la región en momentos oportunos. El Presidente Xi Jinping destacó que China siempre será un buen amigo y un buen socio de los países de ALC, y avanzará de la mano y hombro a hombro con ALC en su respectiva marcha hacia la modernización, escribiendo juntos un nuevo capítulo de la construcción de la comunidad de futuro compartido China-ALC. El presidente de Colombia y Presidente Pro Tempore de la Celac Gustavo Petro, el presidente de Brasil Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, el presidente de Chile Gabriel Boric, la presidenta del Nuevo Banco de Desarrollo del Brics y Expresidenta de Brasil Dilma Rousseff dieron respectivamente palabras. El representante especial del presidente de Uruguay y próximo Presidente Pro Tempore de la Celac Yamandú Orsi leyó la carta de felicitación del presidente.

title: Beginning of the end of trade war good for all
content: The White House fact sheet on the talks claims that US President Donald Trump "secures a historic trade win" for the US. But some US news media outlets said it's a win for China. Even former US ...
resumen: The China-US agreement reached at their trade talks in Geneva, Switzerland, over the weekend and taking effect on Wednesday is a win-win for China, the US and the rest of the world. The decision arrived at by the world's two largest economies to drop the tariffs by 115 percent has already raised stock markets' indexes in the US and the Asia-Pacific. A CNBC report on Tuesday read: "US-China tariff reprieve is enough to get products on the shelves in time for Christmas", while a CNN headline on Wednesday said: "Tariffs devastated America's ports. Soon, they could face a surge from stockpiling". The 90-day reprieve could be extended permanently. The outcome of the trade talks is encouraging. The author listened to Chinese Vice-Premier He Lifeng speaking at the Sunday evening press conference, and the talk on TV by US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer. The two sides agreed to launch a consultation mechanism on trade and economic issues. It reminds people of the 90 high-level dialogue mechanisms that existed between the two governments several years ago, from the Strategic and Economic Dialogue to the Joint Commission on Commerce and Trade. Back in December, then US president-elect Trump told a press conference at Mar-a-Lago that "China and the United States could work together to solve all the problems of the world". The Geneva talks were a good start for the two sides to put bilateral relations on the right track. The author is chief of China Daily EU Bureau based in Brussels.

title: China Courts Latin America With $9.2 Billion Bet—Challenging the U.S. in Its Own Backyard
content: China has unveiled a massive US$9.2 billion credit line and infrastructure investment fund aimed at Latin American and Caribbean nations. This initiative, announced at the China-CELAC (Community of ...
resumen:
China has unveiled a US$9.2 billion credit line and infrastructure investment fund for Latin American and Caribbean nations. This was announced at the China-CELAC ministerial forum on May 13. Chinese President Xi Jinping opened the summit and pledged billions in development credit and expanded cooperation in clean energy, trade, and infrastructure.

Several Latin American and Caribbean countries are reassessing their economic ties with the United States.

China is positioning itself as an alternative global partner.

Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi urged Latin American ministers to “join hands” with Beijing.

China has overtaken the U.S. as South America’s largest trading partner, with bilateral trade reaching US$427 billion in the first nine months of 2024.

China has signed free trade agreements with Chile, Peru, and Costa Rica. In November 2024, it inked an enhanced FTA with Peru expected to increase trade by 50%.

The Chancay Port in Peru, built by COSCO, cost US$3.5 billion.

U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio warned regional governments that “economic cooperation with the CCP comes with military consequences.”

Of the 33 countries in Latin America and the Caribbean, 22 have signed on to the BRI.

In Colombia, President Gustavo Petro has reportedly shown openness to BRI integration.

China’s investment strategy includes:

*   Electric vehicle (EV) factories in Mexico and Brazil.
*   Lithium mining projects in Argentina, Bolivia, and Chile.
*   Hydropower plants and solar farms.

Between 2005 and 2020, China’s two main policy banks issued more than US$141 billion in loans to Latin American governments.

The U.S. Southern Command has flagged Chinese-operated ports like Chancay as potential military assets.

The Espacio Lejano space tracking facility in Argentina, operated by the Chinese military under a 50-year lease, has raised fears that it could be used to monitor U.S. satellite activity.

Huawei is active in many Latin American markets, providing 3G and 4G networks and working with Brazilian firms to prototype 5G technology. Surveillance systems developed by Huawei are now active in Peru and Bolivia.

Brazil, under President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, has pushed for a multipolar world order.

Mexico has seen increasing Chinese investments in key industrial sectors.

The Biden and Rubio administrations have announced counter-initiatives to reengage Latin America, such as the Americas Partnership for Economic Prosperity (APEP) and expanded loans via the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB).

title: La UE destina 120 millones de euros a ayuda humanitaria para América Latina y el Caribe
content: Bruselas, 15 may (EFE).- La Unión Europea destinará 120 millones de euros a ayuda humanitaria para América Latina y el Caribe en 2025, con los "más vulnerables" de Venezuela, Colombia y Haití entre lo ...
resumen: La Unión Europea destinará 120 millones de euros a ayuda humanitaria para América Latina y el Caribe en 2025. Los «más vulnerables» de Venezuela, Colombia y Haití serán los principales beneficiados, tras recientes desastres naturales y conflictos armados. La comisaria de la Preparación y la Gestión de Crisis, Hadja Lahbib, dijo que esta nueva financiación de la UE permitirá a sus socios humanitarios seguir prestando asistencia vital donde más se necesita. Parte de esa ayuda también reforzará la preparación ante desastres. El anuncio de esta ayuda coincide con el primer aniversario del Memorando de Entendimiento sobre gestión del riesgo de desastres entre la UE y América Latina y el Caribe, firmado en Barbados hace un año. En Venezuela, se destinarán 38 millones de euros a organizaciones humanitarias. En Colombia, 21 millones de euros apoyarán a las personas desplazadas por conflictos armados. Más de 7,7 millones de venezolanos han huido de su país desde 2015, de los cuales más de 2,9 millones viven en Colombia, mientras que alrededor de 1,5 millones buscaron cobijo en Perú y alrededor de 500.000 respectivamente en Ecuador, Chile y Brasil. La UE asignará otros 10 millones de euros a países en América del Sur para ayudar a esas personas desplazadas forzosamente y en riesgo. La misma cantidad irá a Centroamérica y otros 10,1 millones a la preparación ante desastres. Ecuador recibirá 2 millones de euros. En el Caribe, Haití recibe más de 18 millones de euros. Otros países caribeños recibirán más de 8,5 millones de euros.
